content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												"Over? Oh it's not over until I teabag every last one of you alien mother f***ers" - Sam 'Serious' Stone, Serious Sam 3THE GOODThe Serious Sam series has always been an antidote to the shooters which may or may not have a player character who kills off people who are different to them because they look different, sound different and speak different languages, in where you have a whole lot of aliens trying to trample and shoot you from all sides, just like the 4:17pm on December 24th. There weren't any key card quests, no escort missions, and no real story which was involing in any way. The gameplay may turn off hardcore Serious Sam fans for the first few levels. Few enemies will attack you systematically while you kill them off in a straight line. After you reach the Shpynx however, it starts to hit the fans and the aliens who outnumber the amount of Steam gamers with light wallets will charge and generally blow you to pieces. Just like the good old days.THE GREATRemember when you realised that you could play co-op on some of your favourite games? It was the dogs ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (Pretty satisfying) wasn't it? Whatever gamemode that has co-op elements in this kicks all kinds of alien♥♥♥♥♥ and there's nothing more enjoyable than decapitating a demon which you woke from it's slumber with something that resembles a laser whip from Star Wars. Be it Beast Hunt, Coin Op or just straight out Classic Co-op, it will be a helluva good time, especially with the customisation involved in it.THE UGLYCroteam, we love your level design. Serious Sam TFE and TSE were fantastic! We'll blame SS2 on the annoying child that kept pestering you on the next Serious Sam game who said that his father/older sibling played it and he wasn't allowed to. At least you regained your thing with the singleplayer in this. For the most part. The first few levels have you going through corridors killing off enemies not for fun, but simply because they're in the way. There is little reason to like the first few levels for many people, which will turn off some players. Later into the campaign you get cannons and miniguns and so on, so fourth, but here's a comparrison. In the first level of TFE, you get a rocket launcher, a double barralled shotgun, a single barralled shotgun, you fight off biomechs and witch harpies (If you find all the secrets at least). In the first level of TSE, you get a rocket launcher, both shotguns, a sniper, a chainsaw and a flamethrower while killing witch harpies, arachnids and lumberjacks with pumpkins for heads weilding chainsaws. And the best you find in BFE is a shotgun, some ammo for the assualt rifle and a few kleers and gnarrs? I know which I prefer. Also, a few mechanics like sprinting, aiming and reloading have been redundantly been introduced, but those are mostly optional, so not too bad.THE VERDICTOverall not a bad game. Worth getting on sale, but do not judge the game on the story and the singleplayer alone. If you get through to the sixth or seventh level, it will ramp things up a bit. And that's a promise.SIMILAR GAMES-Any first person shooter from Id Software before 1999-Painkiller and Serious Sam TSEFor more reviews check out http://steamcommunity.com/groups/truereview

content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												The Serious Sam series is some of my favorite FPS games I have ever played. I played the first 2 when they came out and thought "why don't more FPS games do this?" Sending hundreds of enemies at you is extremely exhilarating. I never seen any other game do this like the Serious Sam games. You feel amazing as you try to dodge hundreds of enemies and their projectiles all at the same time.I always thought The Second Encounter was the best in the series, until I played this one. It feels a lot more modern and I love how the enemies look when they explode into bits and pieces. They got rid of the annoying trap rooms from TSE (I always thought they were badly designed) and upgraded the level design. The physics engine makes the majority of the levels have breakable walls. This creates some awesome gunfights, when you have tons of enemies blasting things at you and walls are breaking all around you while you try and shoot back at them.The Serious Sam series is also known for their final levels and just how brutal and awesome they can be. Over 1,000 enemies coming at you? Check. Nearly 2 hour level? Check. Huge boss fight at the end of the level? Check. Seriously difficult? Double check. I think this game has the best final level in the series. The music and enemy formations, just made everything seem so perfect. Good luck ever beating the level on Serious difficulty.This game will last you around 15 hours on Normal difficulty. There are other game modes you can play and the real strength of the game comes from playing the Campaign on Serious difficulty. Every FPS fan needs to try this game.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												When i first opened Serious Sam 3 BFE i teared up. It was such a beautiful moment that it took me back to the first time i ever played Serious Sam - a unique,unforgettable and exquisite franchise that got me into the FPS genre. About Sam 'Serious' Stone: There isn't much to be said about Sam Stone, except that he is a total destroyer of  Mental's world. His serious personality has inspired me for so long and now in this prequel of the first encounter i felt his anger and frustration in level 11 when his whole squad was wasted. Oops, spoiler i guess. Gameplay: You can start playing this game by choosing one of the 3 modes: Single Player, Multiplayer or Versus. For me the most memorable parts i ever had with this game were in MP. I have never experienced so much carnage and fun that can reach the ridiculous amount of 16 players in co-op. I personally reccommend that you join the steam group called '7smoke'  in order to enjoy online play without any speedrunners. There is also survival mode that throws you into a battle arena of countless waves of enemies. For those of you who enjoy playing solo, i must warn you. Don't click on 'serious' if you are a newcomer to the franchise. The final mode is Versus and for me this was a bit of dissapointment in comparison to the brilliant Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter versus. The double-shotgun is ridiculously overpowered, the maps aren't that good, a lot of rage quit and tons more stuff that annoys me, but still could be fun if you play with the right people. We must not forget that Serious Sam 3 BFE has full workshop support that has a lot of interesting mods from people that are really creative. So you can play christmas mods during the holidays, halloween events and etc. If you can't find the right map or character skin you want to play with you can create it yourself with the new Serious Editor 3.5. And to wrap this short review up i must tell you that Serious Sam 3 BFE is an easy 10/10 for me, but only because this is my childhood game and i love every addition to it. For newcomers that have never played Serious Sam before i can recommend this game with all my heart, and hope that this game will have the same impact on you that it had on me.  Stay serious folks !

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Is this another typical shooter? Yes and no. The game play and the art style does it's best to differentiate itself from anything else.I'd like to first mention the fact you can choose a third person view. This game does it's best to give you every option in the book and by simply adding this just means the devs care. One thing about the third person view, when the player backs up into a wall (not facing it), the camera switches to first person view. This is done I'm assuming so we don't get any camera clipping through the walls. It can be annoying, but some will probably find that brilliant. Whenever there is scenery that can break, or that gives a reaction back when hit, I'm definitely a fan of. Serious Sam has a lot of weapons, some that can be used with variance. The hammer for instance, can break through wooden planks or when X is pressed (on an X-box controller), Sam instead of swinging forward, does a whole ballerina spin to knock everyone out. If Sam hit's a wall, dust comes off it! Not everything breaks, but there is quite a bit you can hit and still get something out of it. Heck, if that sort of close combat melee isn't enough, when an enemy gets close, hit the A button to do a custom melee take down. You even get a trophy to throw once you do this. Weapons are somewhat basic but as the story line progresses, they do as well. All basic movements are given in this game which is absolutely fantastic (sprint, duck, jump). One addition that may have helped would be something as seen in Dishonored, where you can climb certain obstacles. Once in a while, you may find yourself trying to get up a stairwell you simply cannot. It may not seem obvious at first, but after multiple tries you finally realize you were maybe not supposed to go there. The enemies in this game are by far differentiated from the rest of the FPS world. My personal favorite is this guy running with two bombs in his hands, and yells at the top of his lungs as he is approaching you. Most of the time you have no idea where this guy is either than hearing his voice, and it's a scramble to find him. Blood type can also be switched in options. Don't like red? Go green? Don't like green? Go hippie.... (seriously). The game provides quite a challenge on one player and can be very fun on local-coop. Visuals and sounds are really good. The menu is easy to navigate and brilliantly done. The game's graphics are quite consistent and have not noticed any chopping. Sounds are welcomed as well as dialogue throughout the game. Sam does make a few comments here and there when seeing or dealing with certain enemies. My favorite part I must mention though is the local-coop ability. You can choose to play with 2-4 players and CHOOSE the screen sizes if you are playing with 3 people. Amazing feature once you start playing with friends. I recommend this game as it has local co-op and is extremely fun with friends. Alone, it can still provide entertainment and still worth a purchase. If this FPS had no local co-op it would be rated as an average shooter at 7.4-7.5. Because of all the added extras, I'll have to give itRATING : 8.1/10  Gameplay B Story / Campaign B+ Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability B Overall  BScreenShots : 3 player local co-op screens. The dude with the bombs yells at the top of his lungs while running towards you, kamikaze style Horizontal and vertical screens are available options, as well as unlimited or limited lives You can set these graphics as blood in-game, and change them anytime you'd like Various forms of melee are in the game, this is what happens when you press A near an enemy I wanted a vertical view, my friend said horizontal has better peripherals And then there are giants like this roaming around

Posted: January 30
												Serious Sam 3: BFE+ The menus are accessible, the opportunities beyond the single player game are impressive, and the game runs smoothly throughout.+ (GRAPHICS) There's a sense of environmental deja-vu and less high-end beauty than in many of today's top shooters. But for monsters and monstrous levels of death and destruction, Sam 3 is where it's at.+ (SOUND) Great swells of industrial metal music, crazily verbal enemies, bombastic bombs, and audible gore galore. What's not to like?+ Serious Sam is a wave-based, run-backwards-while-shooting, roller-coaster of doom from start to finish. Variety is not its strong suit, but more weapon/ammo availability should be.Good old Serious Sam gameplay, with impressive graphics! Expect hordes of enemies and loads of co-op fun. For a real challenge, play on Serious Difficulty.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												I love all the Serious Sam games to date, I used to play them as a child and really enjoyed them, thats why I have a lot of confronted feelings about this game, so here it goes:++PROS++-Mindlessly killing hordes of monsters is always fun-Not serious game/dialogue, funny one-liners--CONS---It gets TOO repetitive. Dont get me wrong, killing hordes of enemies is fun... but there is a point, where you are in a zone and enemies keep respawning, and killing them stops being fun an becomes a chore. Near the end of the game there is a section where you have to kill around 3000 enemies of all kinds, which takes you like an hour, all in the same place.-The enviroments: It tried too hard to have "realistic" maps, I mean, with a lot of detailed textures and real-world looking. In my opinion Serious Sam does good with less "serious" textures (which, by the way, dont look that good) and a more cartoony look. Half of the game seems to take place in the same city map and the other half in the same desert map.-The enemies: 85% of the enemies are the same from older games. This isnt a bad thing of course, but the new enemies they added are completely unoriginal and not fun to fight against. Alien soldiers that have human guns and just stand there shooting at you, also, they dont have projectiles you can dodge, but hitscan, which means that you cant dodge their shots. Wellp, imo that goes a bit against what serious sam is supposed to be.I had some fun with the game and enjoyed it at the beginning, but it got repetitive real quick and finishing it was kind of boring.Wouldnt recommend this game for full price.

Posted: January 12, 2016
 Serious Sam 3 BFE(2010). "Alien Hamburger, my favorite"Serious Sam 3 BFE is a great game. You play as Sam Serious Stone. He's the ultimate 80's murican. An action film stereotype. Basically Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sylvester Stallone, & Bruce Willis combined! The title is serious, but the game is hilarious. Great one liners, a comical plot, and monsters that are just over the top. The game play on the other hand is seriously smooth & fast. They added aim down sites which is a must for me. Game play on a controller is excellent. The game features, single player campaign, split screen, LAN, and online multiplayer with 16 player co-op! This is the way it needs to be, hats off to Croteam. (I'm talking to you EA, quit forcing me to play on your server, and give me local co-op or LAN!) Sorry got off track, OK I'm back. The music is just awesome. Mostly Egyptian style background music, but when action gets heavy the music gets heavy. As in METAL. This fits perfectly for blasting Aliens into giblets! The Serious Engine 3.5 is optimized very well, while load times can be a tad long. I found this game would run on almost anything in lower settings (Not your RadioShack Tandy, but anything from 2010 and up should be fine). If you enjoy a game that doesn't take itself too seriously, has a nice arcade feel, replay value, 80's action humor, and offers great co-op game play just stop reading and buy it!Disclaimer: Adult Content, Nudity, F-Bombs, Gore. content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Before the First Encounter (though Battle For Endor sounds much better!) is the 3rd instalment of Croteam's Serious Sam franchise, however, this time the Croatian guys picked the make-it-a-prequel-it-is-catchier road. To be honest, I have no idea what makes it a prequel - story-wise, you still keep shooting at various aliens until every one of them dies.The concept is similar to what Painkiller has: you walk / run along and enjoy the silence and suddenly you hear loud music indicating the oncoming hordes, and I mean HORDES, of enemies. Once you are done with all of them you can proceed to the next section - by only hearing your footsteps - where everything starts over.Your guns are big, using them is very enjoyable and none have the option to be reloaded. You just keep pressing the button until you run out of ammo. Oh, and sometimes there are bigger enemies that are meant to be the bosses. Simple as that.So, the core elements remained the same: it has always been a mindless shooter with Sam trying to sound as cool as Duke Nukem. My opinion is: sometimes he gets it right and sometimes he doesn't. Unlike previous instalments this game looks stunningly beautiful and even though it is already a 3-year old game it requires some high-end components so that you can enjoy the spectacle of blown up enemies and flying body parts!For those who love this genre (or more like: subgenre) Serious Sam is a must!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												If I had to describe my experience with Serious Sam 3 in a single word, it would be: "underwhelming".I bought Serious Sam 3 in the recent holiday sale and played it with a friend in coop from start to finish. Both of us having played every other game of the series, we relatively quickly decided that this part of the series is the least fun to date.The third installment is much more oriented after recent "mainstream" fps games, lacking most of the classic and iconic features, clearly wanting to reach a wider, more casual, audience.During the whole 7-10 hour playthrough, you will face the same enemies with the same standard weapons. They replaced classics like the double revolvers with a generic desert eagle, the tommy gun with an m4. There is absolutely no variation in locations, as the whole game is situated in egypt, starting in a destroyed city almost identical to what Battlefield 3's campaign starts in, and then leading to pyramids and ruins, all looking basically the same. The huge variety of level design, that Serious Sam 2 had, is completely absent, as are the very funny and unique secrets from the earlier Serious Sam titles. There are still secrets in the game, however, they are so boring and anticlimactic, that you just stop looking for them, while you were going through entire levels again just to find that one funny hidden easteregg in Serious Sam 2 or 1. The biggest thing you can find in SS3 are the sniper rifle and plasma gun (which are secret only, which reduces the weapon variety even more) or some additional armor. Serious Sam 3 just doesn't dare to stick to its roots, but rather wants to attract a bigger audience by making itself way  too serious . It almost feels like just another generic shooter. Even Sam's oneliners just seem off and boring in this game.They added melee executions to the game, which means you can run up to enemies, press "e" and instantly kill them with a short animation, which is fun at the start, but later becomes so spammable that it makes usage of weapons so absurd, because it takes much more ammo and time to shoot than to just one hit melee people. Bigger enemies cannot be meleed, and they usually stay back and spam you with infinite-range rockets or machine guns, making them annoying because you often lack effective long range weapons.Now, there are still good sides. The soundtrack is amazing, the gore is pretty nice and coop still can be fun. If you didn't like the "ridiculous"-approach of Serious Sam 2, then you might like SS3. If you, however expect, a creative, crazy game, you will be disappointed, just like I was. The whole game feels like a drag, like one long-stretched level, as you walk from ruins to pyramide to desert to ruins to pyramid to ruins again, and then finally to an unsatisfying boss fight resulting in the ending credits. After two levels you have seen all enemy types, almost all weapons, and all mechanics. There are no vehicles, turrets, almost no jumping puzzles, just straight up walking and shooting wave after wave of the same, annoying enemies, always with the thought "please be the last enemy" or "please let me exit this desert already".I was really looking forward to playing Serious Sam 3, I went in with a lot of motivation and I really wanted to like this game. But instead of another fun installment, this just became a generic shooter, with almost no resemblence to the series, lacking so many iconic features. That is why I don't recommend this game to fans of the series at all. It is the worst Serious Sam game so far, in my opinion.Just a quick list of things missing compared to earlier installments:- multiple locations (--> also varying enemies)- unique bossfights- iconic weapons have been replaced with generic ones- unique and rewarding secrets- a lot of humour- varying gameplay mechanics, such as vehicles or turrets- power-ups (including the Serious Bomb)- puzzles and jumping passagesIt might still be a solid coop experience, but nothing more. Maybe people prefer the barebones version, that focuses only on shooting, but I'd much rather recommend SS2 or First and Second Encounter.TL:DR 10 hours of the same levels, enemies and weapons. Almost no variety and imo, the worst installment of SS yet, as it lacks almost all classical features.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Unless you're a die-hard fan who yearns for new experiences after having played every other Serious Sam, don't get this.Buy the Second Encounter of the Serious Sam games instead.BFE adds features to the series like putting a dung heap into your favorite pie recipe which creates an extremely irritating parody/mocking of the previous games. These features include sprinting, ironsights, weapons that suddenly have to use magazines, hitscan enemys and a really bad melee system.Some small-minded fanboy might say that I have the option not to use any of these but it is clear as day other aspects of the game had been changed to fit around your great new "features".Sprinting allows you to walk faster forwards at the cost of not being able to shoot. Running and gunning always had been the core functionality of the game so this is a genius move. Optionality is not a counter-argument since enemy speeds have been increased to "counteract" the sprinting ability, making enemys such as Kleer annoying to deal with because they have 200 meter jumps which normally ended up in good shotgun range but now make a succesful dodge half as rewarding.Weapon magazines on the Tier 1 Shotgun and M4 are there to slow down your fast paced shooter and make sure you enjoy your time actively doing absolutely nothing.The increased amount/strength of hitscan enemys ensures your run and gun fast paced shooter turns into a blow-trading cover based waiting-simulator. While the previous games had hitscan enemys that would instantly shoot on sight but have poor long-range capabilities the ones in this game have to be baited to shoot after which you wait out their shooting behind cover until you can return fire. Rinse and repeat with a lot of waiting. Waiting is fun I enjoy it a lot thank you.The bad melee system allows you to instantkill certain enemys once you are close enough at the cost of being locked in a killing animation(it won't look satisfying the 2000th you do it I can promise you that). More waiting, thanks a lot. I would truly let this "feature" slide if it wasn't for the fact its the only way to get rid of the new giant bug enemy type which is merely a bullet sponge. It is less frustrating to use the melee instantkill on them en masse and works (it shouldn't) because their AI does not have a proper reaction to close quarters combat with the player.Graphics are grey, mediocre and uninteresting. Enemy designs have been reduced to tones of grey and red. For some reason the Doom mancubus is in this.On the good side, the second half of the game gets slightly better as it attempts to ape the previous games. If you can wade through the first half, that is.The music is also nice I guess.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												I'm two minds about this. Some parts of this game were fun. Some parts. The others were not. If you're a serious fan of the SS franchise, you might want to convert this to a thumbs up.I expected a mindless carnage shooter and I got it, that part is fine. The environments could be a bit more varied, but it's OK. The enemies are fine. But the level design, oh my god. I'd love a corridor shooter (with actually wide areas, but linear). But in this case, you're constantly looking for something, often you don't even know what, and are just backtracking and wandering until finally you find a key or a switch somewhere. There are maze-like passages, often in a complete darkness (underground), where you spend an hour looking for a nearly invisible lever (honestly, I had to open up a let's play on youtube twice just to figure out how to proceed, in a game that's supposed to be a mindless shooter!). This was killing the fun quickly, I want to kill hordes of enemies, not spend tens of minutes wandering around looking for something. The humor could've been better, I think, there are just a couple of phrases throughout the whole game and that's it. The underground passages were extremely annoying and overused (once would've been fine). The "space monkeys" are extremely irritating (that is the point, I get it) and again overused, also kill the pacing. The performance is abysmal - I can play Witcher 3 but hardly play SS3?I think the full price is ridiculously high for this, I recommend you to buy this in a serious discount, if you want it. I enjoyed about half the game and suffered through the rest. Overall I was quite disappointed from it.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												For each step taken forward, another step was taken back.Serious Sam 3, where do we begin with you? I grew up playing all of the Serious Sam games, starting from the very beginning. I've played most of the spin-off games as well, along with that god awful GBA port. I'll say as much; Serious Sam 3: BFE, is probably my least favorite game out of the main series. It doesn't mean it was bad, but it certainly needs a retrospective in the development of the next game.Serious Sam is, for all intents and purporses, a parody game of the gratituous action flicks of the 80s and 90s. Unlike Duke and his bravado of being an unflappable badass, Serious Sam opts to take a more corny approach. He comes off more like Ash from the movie Army of Darkness than John Matrix from Commando. Full of self-references and indulgence for making quips about the ridiculousness of it all, peppered with plenty of black comedy, it works wonderfully by itself.Serious Sam 3 does get plenty of what made the original games did right. The guns feel fantastic, Sam is still a talkative hardass and most of the classic enemies have returned, with some minor changes. Running jokes, running and gunning, it's all great fun. The graphics are stellar and everything feels crisp. In games like these, the plot takes a backseat to the gameplay at hand, and for good reason. All we know is that Sam's gotta bust an alien army and save the world, that's it. Anything else acts as a transition between levels and sets up the scene. When it comes to controlling, there is only one flaw I can think of and it pertains to Sam's unusually heavy jumping, making platforming somewhat of a hassle.Despite staying true to the original Serious Sam, specifically the First Encounter, it is ultimately the biggest flaw - it stays TOO close to the original. All of the levels are in Egypt. You get a wide variety of: open desert, desert with shrines and temples, underground desert temples, and desert favelas. None of the creative, interesting levels from the Second Encounter or Serious Sam 2 make an appearance in this game. As a result, the game gets VERY repetitive in a short amount of time, which is further compounded by the sheer size of levels in Serious Sam games. Much of the humour relies on one-liners and banters, which isn't necessarily a bad thing in itself. However, SS2 went way out of the box and went balls to the wall with silliness, so it's a shame to see 99% of it getting passed over in this rendition. NETRICSA, Sam's "in-game guide" so to speak has also been neutered as well, offering less information from before and just not worth reading, whereas in previous games, you could read the data sheets of enemies and get a glut of both funny and useful information.Had there been more level and environment variety with a bit more risk taken, this would have been a much better game. But I can't fault it for what it is, it's still Serious Sam. Buy it when it's more than 50% on sale and you'll get, what I feel, is the right pricepoint for it.6.5/10.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
This is a long review, so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend this game skip to Results and read from there.Croteam continues the epic saga that is Serious Sam pushing the foundations why this game tests time. Serious Sam 3: BFE is a brilliant rendition of all the elements that made this game so seriously epic. Story:Serious Sam 3: BFE is a prequel to the Serious Sam The First Encounter. The world is under attack by Mental and his forces as Sam and his team must retrieve research data behind the Sirian weapon system that could be the key behind defeating the world’s most devastating foe. As all of Sam’s comrades fall and he pushes the forces of Mental down one by one the world falls into dust and it would seem all is lost. Using his trusty comrade Netrisca Sam is able to solve the Sirian puzzle and land right where Serious Sam The First Encounter Begins. Campaign:Serious Sam 3: BFE is divided into twelve levels that gradually increase in length. The levels start out rather short, but extend in length lasting reaching over an hour and a half each. There are six difficulties which scale brilliantly: Tourist, Easy, Medium, Hard, Serious, and Mental. Beating the campaign on Serious unlocks Mental difficulty, which adds a whole new element to the campaign. Even on Serious Difficulty you will essentially be slaughtering waves of enemies that will fall to your feet as if you were a wolf amongst lambs… The sea will run red with the blood of your enemies!!! The easier the difficulty the more ridiculous the slaughter will be, depending on how you play you may enjoy the easier skills. The campaign has epic puzzles and brilliant boss fights that keep you on the edge of your seat. Most of the bosses throughout the game are mostly just regular enemies that are slightly stronger; although, two of the bosses Ugh-Zan IV and Alcor Class Warship are brilliant new editions to the game that relate to the original story.Gameplay:Serious Sam 3: BFE follows suit with the other games in the series. You play a complete and total bad♥♥♥♥♥modeled after a 80s action hero as you defeat thousands upon thousands of enemies. The game boasts fifteen weapons: Fists, Sledgehammer, Axe, Sirian Mutilator, SOP38 Pistol, 12 Gauge Pump-Action Shotgun, Double Barrel Coach Gun, M29 Infantry Assault Rifle, XM-214-A Minigun, XPML21 Rocket Launcher, XL2 Lasergun, AS-24 Devastator, RAPTOR Sniper Rifle, C-4 Demolition Charge, and SBC Cannon. The combinations of epic weapons give you a huge diversity of methods to defeat the mass enemies that are ahead of you. Jewel of the Nile DLC:Jewel of the Nile is a fantastic addition to Serious Sam 3 BFE. This addition changes the dynamic of SS3 BFE by changing the game from a mass shooter to puzzle solving. The levels resemble more of a DOOM or Shadow Warrior style where you will be finding secrets and solving puzzles. The DLC includes three levels: Gathering of the Gods, Together Forever, and Born Again. These levels make the secret weapons more available and the jetpack from the final boss fight a featured element. This DLC offers amazing new features and includes epic boss fights to boot. Hints:>I would recommend looking up where to find the secret XL2 Lasergun and ammo as if you don’t you probably won’t get to use it.>I would recommend looking up where to find the secret RAPTOR Sniper Rifle and ammo as if you don’t you probably won’t get to use it. >I would recommend looking up where to find the secret SBC Cannon because it’s just fun to use, although you will get it later in the game.Results:Serious Sam 3: BFE continues the brilliance of the series by pushing the foundation of the original and only making the series that much greater. I would recommend getting this game even if it’s at full price. With DLC added you and Steam Workshop support this game offers more than you could image. SS3: BFE plays like an 80s action movie where you play an amazing hero who runs in guns blazing and kills thousands of enemies while only getting minor scratches. Pros:+With fifteen different weapons you will never be bored.+Twelve fantastic levels that are all unique and incorporate new features and elements. +Many different enemies, some new some old, that keep you at check.+Loads of secrets that increase replay value and make you want to scour the levels.+A jetpack for the final boss battle making taking Sam to all new levels (get it, because he can fly)+So much nostalgia, so much feels.Cons:-Some of the weapons are secret and you will not get to use them if you don’t find them.-The sun shines into your eyes essentially blinding you at certain points in the campaign.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												I will start off by saying that I have played and finished all the PC SS games, (FE, SE and SS2) and own their release date boxed versions, so I love the series. But BFE is tedious, has zero new ideas, repetitive environments, boring level design, and annoying new enemies. I completely felt like Croteam lost their way with it, and forgot that what made original SS games stand out was the fact that they went against the industry norm at the time, and did something fresh. With SS3 not only did they repeat most of what the older games did without building on it, they also added a whole bunch of unoriginal elements copied from modern shooters. Simply put, this is a boring game because it doesn't do anything new as a SS game or as an FPS Action game. I only got half way through it back in 2013, and then started playing it over in 2016 thinking maybe I just wasn't in the right mood to enjoy it back then, but that wasn't the case. I only managed to finish it by forcing my self to play it, and only because I couldn't stand not finishing a Sam game. Serious Sam 2 gets ragged on by SS fans a lot, but it's a much more fun game then this.  Anyway, I post this review in hopes that maybe it will have some kind of influence over SS4, which I am very much anticipating. I hope Croteam realizes that SS formula has been copied and improved on in recent years, by games like Shadow Warrior (2013) and the new Doom, which means they have to do a lot more then build a same game with new levels and better graphics. People forget how influential first SS game actually was, it took the FPS games out of the scripted corridors and put the focus back on fun, Painkiller and the new Doom would not be games they are if it wasn't for Serious Sam. Serious Sam 4 needs to feel fresh again, just like FE did all those years ago. TLDR: Many long time serious Sam fans will most likely find BFE boring, I would really only recommended this for people who haven't played SE and FE.

content:
Posted: January 4
												Yes, I think this is a good buy... if getting on a good sale or in a bundle.  If you liked the first two Serious Sam games, then most of the game will seem very similar.  Hundreds and hundreds of enemies to kill.  Some fun weapons.  Gore.  To be honest, even though this game is about 5 years old, the developers did not stop patching it.  I still feel as of this day of my review that some parts of this game was not optimized well.  The graphics can stutter at times.  Having a 1070 card and still seeing what I saw with an Nvidia 460 as fair as some graphics problems, it seems that again some parts were not written well.  Sam's face when he talks seems off.  The animation to swing the sledgehammer or axe or to perform melee on some enemies was off as well.  However, this game can look really nice.  Some people have complained about the dust clouds; while this could hinder sight i.e. killing the next several enemies, it was "realistic" from a standpoint of sometimes killing or destroying something left a mess.Voice acting is okay.  There are some decent one liners from Sam just like in the first two games.  One turnoff for me was the use of the f word, which I felt was not necessary.  Gameplay was something that was not consistent in pacing.  The first segments of the game felt disconjointed compared to mid game or late game.  If you hate going forward a little only to have to go back due to a flood of enemies, then some of the later levels may be frustrating.  The end boss of the main campain and the end boss of the DLC Jewel of the Nile can be an exercise in patience of learning what to do.  You may want to pick third person mode/perspective for some parts.  So, I have listed some concerns, why would I recommend this title?  Again, if you liked the first two titles, then you will enjoy more of the same with this title; light puzzles, tons of enemies, frag/gore, guns, melee, some humor, different difficulties for a challenge, fun soundtrack, old fashion shooter, steam workshop/mods.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Serious Sam 3: BFE is a first-person shooter video game developed by Croteam and published by Devolver Digital. It is part of the Serious Sam series and a prequel to The First Encounter. The game's story takes place in the 22nd century, during Mental's invasion of Earth, as implied in The First Encounter. The game is set in Egypt and features a 16-player co-operative campaign mode, as well as 4-player splitscreen. The game was released on November 22, 2011 on Windows, October 17, 2012 on Xbox Live Arcade, while the PlayStation 3 version was released on May 13, 2014.Like previous titles in the series, Serious Sam 3: BFE involves fighting against many hordes of enemies in wide-open environments. However Serious Sam 3 has more closed environments than its predecessors, particularly in the early levels. There are also a larger number of enemies that can attack the player from a distance.The player can carry an unlimited amount of weapons, including a minigun, rocket launcher, assault rifle and a cannon. There are 13 weapons total. 5 of them have a manual reload. The signature close-combat weapons from the first game, the knife and chainsaw, have been replaced with a sledgehammer with three modes of attack (vertical strike, 180 turn and full 360 turn).When I said the 360, I know you first thought of 360 Spin, also, no scope :)))))))There is no regenerating health, instead there are health and armor power-ups scattered throughout the levels that the player must pick up. Additionally, the levels are full of secret areas, where health, armor, ammo and in some cases, weapons from later levels can be found, following the tradition of the previous games. Some weapons such as the Lasergun and the Sniper Rifle and their respective ammunition pickups are in fact secret-only, and otherwise are not found in the levels normally. There are no puzzles, however the player must find keys, pull levers and find environmental anomalies to progress.Classic enemies such as the Beheaded Kamikaze, Beheaded Rocketeer and Kleer Skeleton return in the game. New ones include the Khnum and Scrapjack (resembling the Hell Knight and Mancubus from Doom, respectively), as well as the cloned soldiers reminiscent of the Strogg from the Quake series. The Kamikaze has returned to his original design, rather than the Serious Sam II design. The Gnaar's design has radically been changed from the original game. It is now much larger, differently shaped and walks on all fours, unlike its bipedal counterpart in Serious Sam.Rate: 11/10

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Can't recommend it at anything resembling full price, really. They took a good shot at it, but ultimately the earlier games were just better in terms of level design, and while Serious Sam 3 has more elaborate graphics, they're also more ANNOYING graphics as enemies are constantly obscured by dust clouds and other purposeless effects.The final boss was also seriously lame, and it was hard to tell whether they were trying to make fun of SERIOUS MODERN SHOOTER plotlines or actually thought they were writing a good one. Serious Sam 1 and 2 are going to remain my favourites of the series, but the middle of Serious Sam 3 is pretty good.The start suffers from just a serious lack of fun weapons, and the end just has... too many interminable waves of enemies. They just keep coming in dribs and drabs even once the initial rush of potential annihilation is gone and you're just left going: "When is this gonna stop so I can move on?"

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Not a game I believe have a lot of understanding of to review, but it's not like there's much to understand, or need to. This is an old school first person shooter and that is simply the best way to put it. Don't look at the word 'serious' in its title expecting something serious, because this game is just filled with blistering death and explosions. It is especially fun when playing with your friends, either in co-op or versus (the latter in particular being packed with an insane amount of adrenaline). While the environments don't vary much, the level design is overall splendid. There's just an unfortunate lack of polish within the game though, despite that, the dialogue's funny, the guns are entertaining to use, and the enemies have a nice amount of differing designs. It's a very good game for the budget it has. 7.8/10.0

												the most serious game ever made no joke lolwell this is the 3rd game in the serious sam series but the plot tells what happens before the first game ( how did sam travel to the past), BFE stand for before the first encounter which means chronologically it's the first game in the series, so i recommend you to play this one first then go get the first and second encounter HD remake then serious sam 2 to understand the entire plot .-graphicly it's really beautiful and stunning (runs on serious engine 3.5) run it on ultra and still got 60fps .-gameplay is a bit different from old serious sam games , this time you can reload your weapons also new type of weapon ( melee and new pistol ,new shotgun ,rifle...ect ) and new bosses, new game mod online or co op and split screen , funny moments , easter eggs and reference are present in this episode too but the game get sometimes really hard until it becomes ridiculous especially the last one where you have to fight 1740 monster )-as always the voice acting is excellent , metal music , great sound effects-online game is good , alot of mods for co op or versus but sadly not a lot of people are playing it so you will find the servers most of the times empty ( doesnt help when you want to get achievements except if you have friends that have the game too)-no bugs or glitches ( the devs update the game each time they find something isn't working right)-most of the achievements are easy to get but others are a bit hard cause they are only obtained by playing online and not a lot of people are playing it-steam trading cards.i highly recommend this game for those who want a serious hardcore challenging game ( if not you just play on easy ) and get the dlcs too (they offer some good extras and a good solo campaign (3h of gameplay) ) worth the money but you can grab it on sales ( dlcs on sales are 0.99$  )9/10

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Ah, SS3. Here's the tl;dr: =======(steamfriend): so I really dunno wtf to do in SS games.OOO67VH: kill♥♥♥♥♥♥br>=======Now, the review.  ----- 6/10 above average, barely -----  Thank you, Steam Friend, for prompting this review.This review is for those who don't know Sam and haven't played the other SS games.Unlike Sanctum2, Borderlands2, Team Fortress 2, Killing Floor, Left 4 Dead 2 (differentiated characters co-op), Serious Sam 3 is essentially:- wildly killing things.In co-op, add these astonishing features:- several people running around; - i think they're killing things too;- dying;- running back to kill more things.Sure, it's similar to Sanctum 2 or Borderlands 2 in that regard. It's snarky, like BL2. That's always a plus.But there is a sense of teamwork in other games. Kiting (leading on a baddie to get his back turned to another shooter). Specialization. One-two punches. Syncopating bullet storms.One, new to co-op, might wander in SS3 to a point where one is both lost and seeing zero baddies, and the game might stay that way for that person for 5 minutes. Lost, with 'fighting sounds somewhere over there'. That's silly.Here's the rub: there's absolutely zero incentive for others to notice, much less find the team and fight together. In 2013, that's also silly.Killing Floor/Left 4 Dead 2, OTOH, on Hard, requires that every single member take turns syncopate a bullet storm, have multitasking medics, for the entire team to survive. Don't get me wrong. I enjoy it, though. SS3 is a fast-paced shoot-everything-that-moves game. It, like the other SS, has zero active story and purpose. It's like the original DOOM. The goal is to kill♥♥♥♥♥♥to get to a key, which unlocks a door, so that you can get to kill more♥♥♥♥♥♥DOOM reference!Co-op SS3 means only that more baddies are on-screen and more people are coincidentally playing in the same general map.I have bought it for a few friends. I did the same with Borderlands 2, Sanctum 2, and Killing Floor. We play the living hell out of those games. We've played SS3 just once, I think.But I've played it for hours on solo. It's fun. But it knows its place in gaming. So should you, before you buy it.Better value than easily half the movies I've ever rented.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Serious Sam 3...where do I begin?Starting off, the gameplay is solid. If you have never played Serious Sam, it's an FPS where you take on hordes of alien enemies in large open areas. These enemies range from reanimated EDF infantry to giant god-like beasts that would make any normal man♥♥♥♥♥♥himself. Thankfully, you are given quite the colorful arsenal of weapons, from the humble pistol and shotgun all the way to laser guns and cannons that launch uranium cannonballs. Of course, certain enemies are better killed with specific weapons, encouraging ammo conservation over blindly wasting rare ammunition on enemies which could easily be killed with one or two shots from a pistol.Now, as much as I enjoy the game, it does have its problems. The difficulty can get pretty ridiculous at times, especially if you aren't too good at fps games. like me Also, the lack of a wave indicator or "horde health bar" can make waves feel like they're just padding the game along. The addition of having to reload certain guns every so often, while not usually too much of a problem, can get annoying in intense fights where you have to deal with enemies that both shoot at you from a distance and charge you relentlessly.All in all, Serious Sam 3 is pretty good. I recommend it to anyone who wants a break from the FPS norm.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Good FPS with old school approach. I played the First and Second Encounter when younger and recently the HD version in coop, the 3rd uses the same formula and is competent in offering an arcade FPS which the goal is to shoot everything that moves with big guns.The gameplay is simple, advance through the scenario wiping out hordes of enemies that have their peculiarities, for those who played the first the nostalgia is inevitable when hearing a characteristic scream. The new engine can deliver good graphics and visuals, but at a cost, the game is a bit poorly optimized, the mechanics are basically the same with minor additions. There is no plot, just a context, the emphasis is for the badass personality of the protagonist.It is a simple and brainless shooter, I recommend playing in coop because tends to get boring over the time. 7/10

content:
Posted: November 29, 2011
												The sequel that Serious Sam: The Second Encounter deserves.Serious Sam 3 drops lifes system and toy guns of Serious Sam 2, and brings the crazy over-the-top action back into the series. Some new additions help the game feel fresh, such as a sledgehammer, and enemy-specific melee attacks. You can also complain about the CoD-like sprinting and iron-sights mechanics until you're blue in the face, but theres no denying that they make the game more fast paced and frantic.The campaign can also be played co-op with up to 16 players, and the versus multiplayer is still as addictive and balanced as ever.Somewhat poor optimization here and there, but overall, Serious Sam 3 is one of the most complete and accessible games in the series to date. If you're not a fan of the series, this won't change your mind. But for eveyone else, give it a try.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												Here goes my first attempt at a "serious" review. Serious Sam 3 has great gunplay and customization.That being said there were several questionable choices made by the developers such as:-Extremely slow first few levels and super long levels over all: When all you have is the shotgun and imo boring assault rifle the first few levels are really rough, tons of hitscan and lame monsters like the technopolip a person might get the wrong idea about the game in general. Later it's a lot better though. Sad because the other Sams are fun the whole way.-Enemy trickle effect: Lets slowly let enemies pile into the playing field instead of doing them in nice clear waves so players get bored standing there killing 1-3 at a time. Okay. Yeah this speaks for itself, super annoying. Last level this is SUPER awful and annoying. Artificially extends the game length like a half hour at least.-Default Performance settings: Are all horrible, to get any kind of FPS out of the game unless your computer is crazy (and mine pretty good) you have to tweak settings a bit. Average Joe gamer is okay with 45 fps but he's usually on a console w/30 fps anyways. This is PC gaming and you should have your midrange presets giving midrange pcs 60+, preferably 100+. But instead its like 5-7 settings that don't get changed that really should so people claim this game has crap performance. Blame the preset options.-Technopolips: Super annoying to fight and when you only have the rocketlauncher to kill them it's just really all around annoying. They can shoot you thru stuff, kill you really fast and chase you around, all while being immune to small arms and having high hp, and ya know, flying. Slows gameplay to a crawl and makes it annoying and not as fun as it should be.-Enemies immune to small arms: No place for this in any SS game, terrible design. Makes weapon caches required, bad design.-Weapon caches: Infinite ammo gets really boring, enemies immune to small arms aren't interesting or fun. Make better more interesting levels please.-Brides: Slow gameplay down, take control away, pointlessly slow to kill because they gotta pop up a few times and you have to look for them, really annoying.-Space Monkies: Terrible, I C'4d the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of those pillars or logged off the game for a while every time i saw these. They hide and attack you around pillars. So there's several places where its just you chasing the stupid monkies around, they aren't really a threat but id rather be mowing down hordes of kamikazes and stuff. Slow gameplay to a crawl as well.-Dark flashlight sequences where you move slow: Slow gameplay, make the game scary, which i can't stand personally, i dont play SS to be scared but to have fun.-OP wrist lightning thing: Just really lame overall, looks cool, should be a gun or something.-OP Devastator: Fun but too much better than the rocket launcher, prefer sniper rifle and grenade launcher instead of weird OP combo gun.-Sam is _too_ Serious and swears constantly for no reason: SS1 TFE TSE were hilarious. I loved SS2's style even tho most ppl didnt. But SS3 my god man, you don't need random pointless love interest for sam, or him cursing constantly. So weird and out of place from the rest of the games.-Animations: 3rd person and some others are really bad.-Egypt: No more god damn egypt lol. Make levels bright and fun like SS2 or TSE.-Laser gun: NOT ENOUGH OF IT, favorite gun in the series!That being said many good choices were also made:-Graphics: Beautiful, awesome looking-Sounds: Some great sounds (gore/rocketlauncher) Some not so great (assault rifle)-Gunplay: Overall fun, not as good as SS1 or SS2 as far as i'm concerned however.-Scrapjacks: Great new monster, pretty fun to fight, i prefer the T-rexes and big red guys from SS2 though.-Gore: Is great in this game.-Last boss: These games always have a gimmick at the end, look at quake or nearly any game like this, keeps the hectic tradition alive.It seems from my review that I might of not liked the game but overall its pretty fun if you like serious sam games and can set it up for decent fps and make it thru the first few painful imo pretty terrible levels. 6.5/10 (+1.5-2)

												This game goes back to the original formula of Serious Sam: First Encounter and Serious Sam: Second Enounter. The setting is strictly desert, and the story has returned to the original idea proposed in Serious Sam FE and SE. The original weapons and enemies make a reappearance, though they are graphically overhauled.In addition, this game's overall feeling is the most Serious out of the 4 main games, as Sam is the most human in this one: Swearing, showing some feeling, and socializing. Definitely a main part of the story.I recommend that if you buy this in a pack, play this one first before all others. This is where, chronologically, the story all began.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Serious Sam 3: BFEI'm a bit biased when I review these kinds of games, I will admit. I've wasted spent countless hours in school playing games such as Counter-Strike, Doom, Quake, Halo, and Serious Sam over LAN, and they've retained a soft spot in my heart as a result. I will try to look at this newest iteration of the Serious Sam franchise fairly, though.GraphicsSerious Sam 3: BFE has received a fresh coat of paint, despite the fact that it still technically runs on the same engine as previous titles. On the whole, I feel positive about this game's visuals, though they're very far from being perfect. It stays true to the Serious Sam art style, and it looks decent enough at first glance. The two main issues are texture detail and the level decoration. The former is simple: Upon closer inspection, textures are lower resolution than I would like. The latter is a bit more complex. Because of how much the game sticks to its drab, somewhat limited Egyptian color palette, it isn't too difficult to get stuck somewhere in a level because you aren't sure where to go next. Despite this, the monsters look fleshy and it is quite satisfying to gib them back to 3000 BC.


Damn Ugly 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam 3: BFE
By: Lavernius Regalis




AudioThe weapon sounds aren't bad, but they won't stick with you as much as the classic weapon sounds in previous games. The enemies all have distinct growls and grovels, and they come to life very nicely when combined with the game's models. Voice acting is about what I expected: Mostly unimpressive, but the one-liners and voluminous vocabulary of John J. D𝗂ck still haven't grown old to me. Additionally, the soundtrack carries on the style of the original Serious Sam: TFE, and goes extremely well with the atmosphere of the game.PerformanceThis game will perform well enough on most systems that meet the requirements; mine easily maxes it out and maintains a comfortable 60 FPS. The one place I really have to complement Croteam with this game is in the graphics options. Serious Sam 3: BFE has, quite possibly, the absolute most detailed graphics options I've seen yet in a video game; I am seriously impressed by how many settings there are.GameplaySerious Sam 3: BFE is a classic first-person shooter that largely revolves around crowd control. It features smooth controls reminiscent of a Doom or Quake game, though this new one introduces a sprint feature which will violently accelerate your character up to the speed of classic Doomguy. The only weapon with a scope is the sniper rifle; while some others do have sights they do nothing besides look pretty and slightly zoom in the screen. Against the style of previous games, weapons other than the player's sidearm now need to be reloaded, but the sidearm retains its classic infinite pool of magazines. Weapons hit hard and fast, and you can carry all at once if you find them. Classic mechanics such as rocket jumping also work to a limited extent in Serious Sam 3: BFE. I found it enjoyable in singleplayer and co-op, but the adversarial multiplayer didn't show off gameplay quite as well.


Ultimate Showdown 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam 3: BFE
By: Lavernius Regalis




SingleplayerThe campaign follows Sam "Serious" Stone as he treks across Egypt in search of some fantastic MacGuffin that will solve all of his problems - and the current problem is the alien invasion that has nearly driven humanity to extinction. While there are cutscenes and other humans in-game, they never assist the player, and typically appear as corpses by the time Sam reaches them. Instead, the campaign finds itself initially playing out like a city-crawling corridor-shooter, but it soon dumps this in favor of classic Serious Sam arenas with massive hordes of enemies to whittle down and endure over. It's par for the course, and I liked it, but the story isn't anything special, so if you're looking for something like Bioshock or a Telltale Games adventure title, look elsewhere.MultiplayerThis game features two multiplayer modes; adversarial and cooperative. I'll cover the former of those two first. It's hardly played at all now, and understandably so: the maps aren't designed particularly well, there isn't great incentive to keep playing, and it clearly wasn't even the focus of the game. The cooperative is where this game shines, however. It features a wide array of options for difficulty and supports 1-16 players, allowing them to play the entire campaign as well as custom maps. Playing alongside three or four other friends attempting to survive against hordes of alien mooks is perhaps the best way to experience Serious Sam, and it is some bloody good fun.Community ContentSerious Sam 3: BFE features a built-in mod menu and decent support for modifications and community content, which raises the question of why there is such a lack of good community content. It is a sad fact that the modifications are largely retextured enemies with different statistics, weapon value modifications, or new cosmetic models for players and their weapons. There is some great potential for custom campaigns, but I haven't been able to find anything that truly takes advantage of that potential yet.


Serious Sam 3: BFE 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam 3: BFE
By: GHOST [PRO]




VerdictWithout a doubt, Serious Sam 3: BFE is a cooperative-focused game. The campaign was designed about as well as previous ones - albeit with a fresh coat of paint and some better presentation - and despite its flaws, this is a good singleplayer/co-op title. The price of $39.99 hurts it a little, because it doesn't quite reach that value, but if you're a fan of classic arena shooters and you find it on sale, you might just find something really enjoyable with Serious Sam 3: BFE.I would recommend Serious Sam 3: BFE, but would suggest waiting for a sale.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												I'm confused why this game isn't very popular in Steam, while Left 4 Dead 2 had a huge success. Serious Sam 3 is like the HD version of Left 4 Dead 2 with increased thrill and gore in the game. Plus you'll smash alien with sledgehammers here rather than shooting zombies. Of course, I can't compare L4D2 with Serious Sam 3 since the base concept of the game is totally different. But both of these are Co-Op games. And both of them gave me the same amount of fun when I play with my own friends. Anyway, here's my review :1.GraphicsStunning graphics with intense amount of blood and gore along the game. Almost every aspect of the graphics beautifully made in this game. The only downside was the crude animation when the characters speak.2.SoundI love the soundtracks ! It really fits your situation in the game and the music changes each time you're in a new situation.3.GameplayThrilling, fun, and challenging. I can't even survive the Normal difficulty after playing FPS for 14 years. I'm also not new to the gameplay style, since I played Serious Sam : The First and The Second Encounter Co-Op with my dad when I was 6 years old. The health and armor supply in the map is really low that you have to fight really carefully to conserve your HP and armor.4.PricingHonestly,it's not really expensive. Your money will really worth it and you'll get what you pay for. There's only 1 DLC and the game is 100% non pay to win. Buy it.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												It's funny how this game which was inspired by Duke Nukem in the first place ends up being 100x better than Duke Nukem Forever. If anything, this game should have been the true sequel of Duke Nukem 3D.Anyway this game is one of the best games in the modern fast paced  style first person shooters, and I myself am a huge fan of old school shooters like Doom, Quake 3 Arena and Duke Nukem 3D. In a time when MOBA's, CoD clones and bland mixtures of both, I gotta congratulate CroTeam personally, they made a game that has that old school charm, that old school difficulty, that makes you rage but at the same time the game rewards you for a job well done, something that most modern games threw it away to appeal to a casual audience (well until Doom 2016 came out but that's another review). In other words, this game stands out from all the FPS garbage we have been fed upon ever since the release of Call of Duty Modern Warfare 2. The replay value is certainly there, the secrets are well hidden. Once again, CroTeam, who were inspired by the fast paced old school shooters, they created a masterpiece. I do recommend fully that you buy this game if you are into fast paced challenging first person shooters and at the same time tired of the bland modern CoD genre. Seriously, this game is worth every cent.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
Serious Sam 3 BFE		* 8/10A new chapter for Sam "Serious" Stone. It's a prequel... Why does it always have to be a prequel?Serious Sam 3 is a classic FPS with a very classic structure. This prequel marks a return to the classic first 2 encounters with renewed graphics, weapons, enemies and a new story. Yes, story. Serious sam isn't exactly famous for its deep story, but this chapter has put some effort in it. Some cutscenes, few other characters and dialogues and some events explaining what sam did before the first encounter. Of course, this isn't a Kojima production, but you can see the difference with the previous chapters.As a classic FPS there's not much to say, mechanics are the usual, and as every other SS you will face huge waves of enemies with the classic arsenal. Actually there's not much to say, the engine is not the Cryengine but Croteam shows a great taste with environments and landscapes building great levels with great visual impact as usual. Enemies and Weapons are the classic as seen in the first encounter, but revisited and kind of updated, with just a couple of news. Music is Badass again, with epic tunes, Heavy boss tracks and some tracks with a touch of tension tracks in some dark and closed map sections (which is kind of new and strange to see in a Serious Sam game... O.o... But kind of welcome, anyways).Shortly, Serious Sam 3 gives us a very good prequel with the classic sarcasm and fun situations, Hordes of enemies to take down with the classic arsenal, everything shown with the new version of the good and trusty Serious Engine.+++Pros+++ ENGINE. The serious engine has never made any miracle but it always showed beautiful landscapes and settings, and this time makes no exception. GAMEPLAY. The classic Waves gameplay is always fun to play as the first 2 encounter, and Sam is always a funny A$$h0l3 whenever e has the chance to talk... Which is quite often... XD COOP. The game is playable in Coop as every other chapter and it's obviously more fun to play. SOUNDTRACK. A beautiful soundtrack again in this chapter with Epic tunes, Badass Heavy boss tracks and even tense tracks for dark sections.---Cons--- LEVELS. Even though there's a good alternation between indoor sections (Temples, dark dungeons) and outdoor locations (the city, Desert), they may kind of look repetitive. For example This never happens in the Second encounter as it has many different themed locations.

												A great single player. And a VERY bad mutiplayer, it's unbalanced, the sniper rifle kills in ONE SHOT even if you have full armor and health, and it's fast almost like a machine gun and it spawns every 30 seconds. So all you have to do is camping that sniper and kill everyone in one single shot. The spash damage of the rocket launcher is too big, so you can't dodge it. (Siplified to make noobs happy) The double barrel shotgun is just too powerful, same thing for the minigun. 1 Inch jumps, you can't shoot while you're running, (Another thing to make things easier). If you have an old PC (Like me) and you're trying to play a dark map with the flashlight belt, you can't see anything, it's just impossible to play. Too much dust when the bullets hits the ground ( You can't see anything) If you  join a match in progress, when it's loading for the match, everyone can kill you because your character is in the game when it's loading to play. Please Croteam, don't make the same mistakes on Serious Sam 4.We want a multiplayer which looks more like Serious Sam HD The Second Encounter, fast, competitive and fun.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Pros:•New styles for killing mobs, Mutilator, melee, etc.•Steam Workshop to help enhance the game if wanted•Masterful Soundtrack•Every level has some secrets to find. Who doesn't love secrets?!•Can either play in First Person or Third Person with a single hit of a button!•Awesome environment detail from either outside or inside•16 Player Multiplayer sounds beast right? Right!•Has 100% controller support; Can switch from controller or keyboard without restarting the game.Cons:•The humor in the game is a bit "dry" compared to the other games.•Game seems easier on Serious difficulty over the older games (First/Second Encounter)•Some of the more higher tier mobs are used as bosses with basically more health.•A few weapons are found only in secrets. (So go find them!)----After you think you've done everything with the game fetching all the achievements possible (Completing Serious difficulty, All Secrets, Old School Mode, Survival Gold Medals, etc.) you should try and complete the game on "Mental x84" Difficulty. No health, armor, 400% more mob health, etc. That's when things get Serious!9/10 Fantastic game.

Posted: February 17, 2012
												Do you like first-person shooters, but hate all the modern "improvements" that the era of Call of Battlefield: Medal of Halo Forever has brought us, such as regenerating health, the "ability" to only hold onto two weapons at a time, and bland generic enemies? Do you want to face an insane amount of enemies with an equally insane amount of weapons, including a ♥♥♥♥ING CANNON? Were you disappointed by Duke Nukem Forever in any way? Then this is the game for you.The only modernizations that Serious Sam 3 went through were the additions of sprinting, melee attacks not involving a weapon, looking down iron sights of specific weapons (pistol and assault rifle), and reloading specific weapons (pistol, regular shotgun, assault rifle, and the Devastator), and these changes feel kind of... welcome, as they aren't abused. Other than that, it's a Serious Sam game. And it is ♥♥♥♥ing glorious.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Game Play: 1st person shooter. Kill everything you see. Carry all the weapons you picked up.Map design: Linear. Maps are huge. Serious Sam series contain the largest map of any FPS. Serious Sam 3: BFE is no exception.How Long To Beat It: Around 22 hours on normal single player. Difficulties On Normal: Very few can solo it on normal . Even on easy it is extremely hard to solo.Kids Rating: Violence. Lots of blood. Swearing. Nudity.Bugs: Crashed one or twice.Game Control: Standard.Save System: Check Point, Auto, and Manual Save System. You can save the game at anytime and anywhere. No limit on save files. Manual save keep the frustration level down.Option Menu: Full control of video and audio.Recommend Buying Price: $5 or lower for general public. $25 or lower for players that loves very hard old style FPS shooter.---I've beaten all three Serious Sam games. Serious Sam 1 is the hardest follow by Serious Sam 3: BFE, and finally Serious Sam 2. Even experts FPS players will have a hard time soloing any Serious Sam games. However in co-ops it is beatable for most players.Serious Sam 3 provide the same classic weapons of it predecessors. From pistol to rocket launcher to cannon balls and everything in between. Like its predecessors you can carry and use all the weapons you pick up. There is no weapon carry limit.The basic game play in all Serious Sam game is the survival of the mob rush. Hundreds of enemies some of them the size of skyscraper will be barreling down on you. Surviving these constant attacks is hard and harder at the end of the game.Not many players can solo Serious Sam games. The alternative way of beating Serious Sam game is to go co-op. Co-op reduce the difficulties and frustration.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												This game, at first I thought would be just an average run-of-the-mill kinda game... but oh my god I was wrong. It's the hardest game I have ever played.The story consists of aliens taking over your planet I think? I'm totally new to the Serious Sam﻿ series but I got the general idea that the world's gone to hell and everything's an alien. You, the protagonist, have to set off to do some magic wonders and escape.. ahem.. lead a slaughter onto the alien race that have invaded the dearly beloved Earth as we know.The first missions are pretty bleak, you're thrown right in at the deep end with no instructions... no map, no real sense of direction, just given a big hammer and infinite swarms of enemies. No, SERIOUSLY (enough puns) you'll be challenged to have to find and activate the invisible enemy spawners yourself (can be found by taking your time through each level) of which will spawn very difficult waves of enemies to fight in limited resources. As the level goes on, you need to hunt badly for health, armour and ammo (and ofc guns) to take on all of the bad guys in the game and fight an array of different creatures such as overgrown Arachnids, Skeleton Rhinos, Mutant Scorpions and my favourite, the Mental Screaming Guy. Very gory and arcade-based, you'll likely be measuring this to the likes of Duke Nukem due to it's cheesy and "serious" storyline, as well as the overall feel very much handles the same however Serious Sam isn't a game to be messed with. I have found this game to be VERY difficult, even as I'm playing on Normal, I've dropped it to Tourist mode and still find completing levels very hard. I'm not sure if it bugs out as cutscenes fail to play or...?It's a heavy-modded game to the PC, a very fun game to get. If you're looking for a reasonably cheap shooter you can net in a bundle or worth to wait for a Steam Sale that will most certainly drive you insane with difficulty, I recommend this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												This game feels like the closest to a real retro shooter with modern visuals in our day and age, it really does, and as someone who have played a few of those, I feel that this kind of game is what most retro FPS veterans wants in their modern shooters. With its maze like levels full with exploration to find secrets and the way to progress, hordes of interesting enemies and bosses with a great variety and an arsenal of weapons. AND YES YOUR HEALTH DOESNT MAGICALLY REGENARATE, you have to find supplies yourself and the same goes with ammo. I have played Duke Nukem 3D and this game feels a lot like it. It may not be a perfect modern-retro shooter, but I think that its the closest we have right now.I cant say a lot about the story and the character since I havent played the previous titles. But for me the story was really that you would expect from a retro shooter and Sam.. oh Sam.. He is so serious! I didnt expect a deep story I just wanted to kick♥♥♥♥♥and chew bubblegun, but since this isnt Duke Nukem, I was all out of gum, and instead I got an awesome first person shooter with a kick♥♥♥♥♥protagonist! I recommend you play it with friends, it doesnt add anything to the story you are just playing as 2-16 Sams, but it is still pretty fun and a great experience with its 16 player max coop (I only played with one though)!This kind of game is what I believe a lot of retro gamers (including myself) hoped/expected to see in the sequel of the amazing Duke Nukem 3D, which we sadly didnt get.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2013
												While at a glance, this game looks like another generic brown and grey shooter and Croteam completely sold out to appease the COD crowd, this game is absolutley like it's predecessors. Sure you can sprint for an indifinite period of time, and you can  aim down sights (I actually really like ADS), but rest assured, everything about this game is Serious Sam. You still fight hordes upon hordes upon hordes of enemies while utilizing a metric ♥♥♥♥ton of weaponry in gigantic environments. I'm not sure whether the modern city environments were either a send up to modern shooters or in fact a very clever message about the state of shooters today though. Multiplayer is pretty cool. There weren't too many people playing versus, so I didn't get the chance to try that out. Co-op on the other hand... You can have up to 16 people playing. While the most I've ever gotten to try out was 8 people (unfortunately, not very many people play multiplayer at all in this game), it was still an absolute blast having so many people contribute to a mindless violent orgy. This game is also quite well optimized, as I get a consitent 30 FPS on my craptop. Ths game is also on the 360, where I played the game's splitscreen (the PC version also has splitscreen, a very commendable move on Croteam's part) with a friend of mine who happens to be a big fan of COD, but is still very willing to try new things. I don't think I've ever heard him laughing so hard mindlessly mutilating enemies with miniguns and killer jewlery. The PC version also has excellent gamepad support, something more PC games should have. The only real issue I have with this game is it's pacing. It takes about 2 to 3 levels for the game to finally hit it's stride. Sure, this a sequence in the first level that reminds you that this is a Serious Sam game, but the next level is without a doubt, the weakest level in the entire game, if not the entire series. But after that travesty, the rest of the game picks up, and when it picks up, it's one hell of a ride. I would absolutely recommend this to anyone and everyone who is a fan of shooting things until they expire. Great game, thanks.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												Serious Sam 3 BFE is seriously one of the best games of its genre and, in all seriousness, an example of how a perfectly built gameplay should be. There is tons of action of course, with cazillions of enemies to battle, especially on the higher difficulty levels, but there is also a good deal of exploration and discovery, together with beautiful and atmospheric sceneries - the post-apocalyptic cities and towns are incredible. You really need to try this game on the harder modes if only to see for yourself how the cleverly made environments, as long as you take advantage of them the best way, are actually your secret "allies" in fighting all those enemies that may seem, on first look, impossible to deal with. There are numerous easter eggs, bigger or smaller nods to many other games, and Sam's hilarious lines. The game has many secrets to look for - some are very easy to find, others require some search. And of course there is the music, one of the most epic and majestic soundtracks you've ever listened, and in particular the masterpiece that is the final boss fight piece.

												When all is said and done, Serious Sam 3 is just plain refreshing. It's nice to have a game that relies so much on flat-out enemy decimation, and which does it so well, so beautifully, and while providing at least the opportunity to share the experience with friends online. If you're weary of todays high profile first person shooters and their endless hype, Serious Sam 3's endless enemies and endless ammo are the perfect antidote. Serious Sam 3 is a game that deserves to be played, because it shows what shooters were and could have been. It shows that there's more to the genre than what AAA developers have shown us in the past decade.Pure mayhem, pure fun, pure Serious Sam, pure first-person shooting.
