number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Serious Sam 3: BFE is the latest addition to Serious Sam franchise, still being a horde-based FPS. And it's a prequel to the first game plot-wise, whoop! BFE is abbrovation for Before First Encoutner, they say. It came out in 2011, being made by Croteam. And it's serious!It also came out for Xbox 360 and PS3. Probably nothing to check out here, maybe it supports less players in multiplayer.Multiplayer community is still there. They mostly play coop all the time. Coop survival is less played. And you are likely to get Versus game only on some hours, who knows, it's not as liked by general people. No one plays modded version of game.That, or you can call your friend to play in split-screen anyway.And yes, you are once again Sam Stone, who is now wearing cool sunglasses. And this time you are going to kill many Mental's minions and maybe rip some eyes. To save the earth! Maybe. As long as you stay serious. Seriously serious!And yep, it now goes back to more realistical setting than Serious Sam 2. And you know what? It's awesome. It's like exactly what I always wanted the next installment of Serious Sam back when I was a fan of the first game, before Serious Sam 2 destroyed the dreams. I mean, cmon, you get to play Serious Sam prequel where you shoot kamikazes in ruined town. It's awesome!And music is still awesome and atmospheric, though this time more forgettable. And scenes are epic. And graphics are great.Then again, some complain that it might be a bit too serious. But I think it's on same level as The First Encounter. It's belivable plot combined with jokish secrets. And small details. That, and yes, it also has dark tomb levels where player even has slower movement speed, being interesting to explore for a change. No worries, it's not Doom 3. And I can agrue that it brought back memories of the third level of First Encounter which is part of what I liked as well. So I am very happy as a fan here.It also added some more of modern gameplay elements into it. At least this is what our usual gamers would call them. But they aren't used as much as one might think and mostly is true only for low-tier weapons.  You can aim with assault rifle and pistol down the sight, which slows you down but makes accuaricy perfect. No worries, minigun still doesn't require any aiming and is accurate like sniper rifle.Few guns also require reloading. It actually fits to pistol and Devastator, a fast-shooting 20-ammo-in-mag explosive railgun thing.  For single-barreled shotgun and assault rifle? Not much. It does make early levels more interesting, having to worry about reloading as rare enemy charges at you. But on bad side, they become mroe painful to use in later levels, so you don't want to change from stronger Double-Shotgun and Minigun. Ok, at least Assault Rifle and Minigun use different ammo, so here is at least "saving ammo".But sprinting is actually a very good addition to Serious Sam franchises. Did you ever think "ok, so it has good speed during battles and I enjoy these huge levels but once I killed everybody walking from one corner of huge valley to another to get all secrets is soooo boring"? Yep, we now have infinite sprint. You can't shoot and can run only forward. So during battle when you dont' sprint the speed and balance is similar to older Serious Sam. And sometimes you can sprint to take a new position, as each arena is much bigger here. It's actually the first Serious game where you can outrun kamikazes this way. And outside of battle it makes it less boring to explore enviroment, taking less time to move on. Perfect addition.And yea, melee kills. They have no gameplay bonus like health regeneration, so you mostly do it for fancyness. After battle. They are tasteful, not as awful as Brutal Doom, no worries.Yep, it's still a good new Serious Sam game. You get new toys to play with. C4 is awesome addition, being hugely explosive. Having a lot of destructable decorations and columns helps to make it super awesome. New enemies. New balance to learn and master. Maybe "space monkeys" that hide behind columns is a bit unfitting to Serious Sam, but they help with variety and motivate you to destroy columns. And hey, new feature weapon, mutilator, is kinda fancy, where you lasso few enemies and they expode after some time of charging up energy. Whoop!Levels are much bigger this time around. Or more exactly, each room is bigger. You aren't as much closed down into arena and you got a lot of room to move. Or even unrestricted at all, which is very different from what we had before. It's still linear, but it's awesome.The only big flaw is how slow and weak the first third of a game is. They go way too slow with giving player new weapons to try out. I mean, I love when I don't get flooded with weapons and options, letting me to savour low-tier weapons for a while. But Serious Sam has two levels in straight where you only have only one non-basic weapon - single-barreled shotgun. And in both levels you fight bulletspongy bosses. Other Serious games would have given you new weapon by that time, letting you think "what should I use in this situation". Really, this is one case where removing a level would have made overall game better.And yep, this game also includes survival game mode that you can play in single-player or cooperatively. Around five maps. Two of them even have you starting with little weapons, slowly giving you stronger enemies and weapons. It's a good fun.Then there are cooperative modes, with infinite respawn or with limited lives. It's a good fun and people will be happy to find out that this time coop mode has cutscenes from single-player as well, which are also skippable. Finally! Not to mentioning that you can play with friend in split-screen.It has versus mode as well. I am not exactly fan of it, the first impession was horrible. Server with infinite ammo and map that has C4 mix awfully. Neither does map where you can exploit to get into rooftop and spam C4. Then there is a level which is nothing but tomb corridors, because all yay super-shotgun reflex and no maneuvering. And Trouble map from old games is now looking both ugly and there are less ways to move due to different physics and scale.But in other maps? Yep, it's still a good fun. No worries, no melee fatalities in this one. It's not terribly unique either, sadly, but it's fun.Overall, it's an awesome game that I always wanted to get as fan of Serious Sam 1. While it has a flaw or few, it's epic and I love that it explores the setting of modern Serious Sam universe before he time travelled. It has that slight apocalypstic feel to it and is just plain Serious. Doesn't dissapoint gameplay-wise either. Thanks, Croteam.

												I heard about the game, when I was young, but never played it. Dont know why. When I first saw it on Steam I thought "Thats awesome! But a lot of bad games look that awesome first."But this game was actually, what it told on the Steam Shop page.It has a completely irrelevant storyIt has a lot of enemysA lot of big gunsYou will never let go of your left mouse keyeverything is coopAll in all its the most senseless and most fun shooter, Ive ever played. It takes the irony of pushed-over-the-limit action, overly masculine characters of modern film and gaming to a whole new level and make a nice not too offensive (unlike Duke Nukem) Joke about it.In the game you destroy everything, from a skyscraper sized spaceship, the sphinx up to to a building sized boss. And thats mostly everything of the game. You run through (mostly very open) one way levels, killing everything, that gets in range and make it to the end of the level.Very impressive is the ability to shoot (most of) your surroundings into pieces, wrecking complete ancient egyptic temples.Being an old type of game genre, you have no lifereg (only on the lowest difficulty) and always have to look for guns and ammunition (there are secrets and specials all over the map, like the laser gun and the sniper rifle).Playing it in coop with other players, doing competitions, speedruns, deathruns and achievments, you can have a lot of fun, if you like just shooting massive waves of enemys.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This is one of my top favorite games ever played on Steam.  It's got some story behind it which is pretty basic.  Serious Sam kicking♥♥♥♥♥on a mission.  The graphics and sound I think is pretty darn good.  I really dig the background music.  I own all the Serious Sam games and they all rock. This game is pretty much about blazing down and blowing up TONS of enemies flying at you.  Sometimes it's like mission impossible with all the enemies trying to kill you.  Plan on getting killed and killing a lot.  They have level difficulties from hard to get yourself killed to them disappearing at times in such large hords you wonder why you selected it.  You can also up how strong the enemies are plus a ton of other game options like infinite ammo, limited lives, etc.They have death match, 16-player co-op, survival, etc game modes.  I run a dedicated server for it.  The main game mode I play is co-op.  Played a lot of 16-player co-op games that were a blast.  Some parts of it are very easy to get lost.  Especially when you go underground.  You can learn a lot playing co-op with others.  Lots of hidden places to find.  The DLC pack is good.The developers are still active patching and improving this game.  The support on their steam community page is top notch.  There is also a workshop for this game if you like to play with game mods.  It's worth playing if you like old school shooters.  Serious Sam 4 is coming out 2017 and I'm looking forward to it!!

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Serious Sam 3: BFE is a brutal shooter set in Cairo, featuring Sam having to deal with a breakout of rampaging aliens.PROS:+ Quite long gameplay (easily 10 hours on just singleplayer)+ Awesome unimaginably overlord weaponry, as well as a decent variety in weapons to use+ Great dose of humor+ Nice graphics+ There is LOTS to shoot. Thousands of enemies per level if not+ Elimination of annoying physics like recoil (that's right, there's no recoil or spread)+ The multiplayer co-op is actively visited and servers are always availabe for both BFE campaign and the DLC campaign+ Tons of secret areas and hidden items+ Expandable with DLC+ Bonus material available (OST, concept art, "making of" videos, etc.)+ Trading cardsCONS:- Gameplay is a lot the same, except for the changing locations and areas- The story is very generic and cliché, but that's due this game revolving around the shooting massacre and is done somewhat on purpose- For a game that has a lot of secrets that you often have to jump and climb to, the jumping in BFE is pretty terrible- Although it does have pretty good music, it has very little variety in itA prequel to a classic and beloved series of FPS, set in a somewhat arcade style. A must for anyone who enjoys action and shooters in general.My rating: 8.5/10

content:
Posted: March 11
												As someone who has been following the Serious Sam series since I first played Serious Sam on the original Xbox, I feel like this game is the most unlike the rest of the series, but in a bad way. We don't talk about Serious Sam 2, because that was also a game that went too off the wall. This version feels like it's getting sucked in to the modern shooter formula. It is still very much Serious Sam at its core - Hundreds of enemies on screen at once where the only tactic is to shoot them all down while strafing the whole time  - it forgets that part of the series' merit was in its humor and overall vibrance as well as the multiple areas featured in the game (like in the first two, where the progression was Egypt > South America > Medieval Europe and the GC/PS2 game was Ancient Rome > Ancient China > Atlantis). The default color settings leave the game in a boring, washed-out, brown and grey world. Thankfully, there's a "vibrant" setting that gives the game the color it needs. The jokes have been copy-pasted and some are downright cringeworthy. I will say, this has to be the more difficult game in the series, with the last few levels being downright unforgivable at some points. It's still a Sam game, and I have to credit it for still sticking to its original formula, but shame it for adding modern shooter features like Iron Sight aiming, muted brown and gray colors, and "military hard♥♥♥♥♥character." Oh, and the two most unforgivable sins in this game: 1) they left out the Serious Bomb and 2) they gave Sam douchelord wraparound sunglasses.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												I'll get straight to the point and say - this game is the worst in the series. There are so many things wrong with this one. Ho Lee Sheet.Cons: Graphics are decent at most with too much contrast for my taste. Lighting is so off in some areas. Sometimes you literally see just black areas and nothing more. Sledgehammer animation is just bad. It can easily give you motion sickness. There are a handful of areas where you are in some caves or dark tunnels and you can only see a small radius with the help of your flashlight. Everything else is just pitch black. Every second you live with the hope that soon you will find a way out of this mess. NO FUN. Ugh! You can't reload your guns while sprinting! That's the dumbest thing I can imagine in a fps game. Especially in this one where you have to fight against 20 enemies swarming at you at the same time. This makes guns like pistol, pump-action shotgun and assault rifle much less preferable to play with.  When you use melee to finish of an enemy - you dash a little bit forward and sometimes it even changes the direction you are facing afterwards. Performance isn't good either. I can play many 2016 AAA games on max settings without any big frame drops, but this game is like a rollercoaster. You can go down from 100 fps to 60 fps in the blink of an eye. Bad level design. Seriously. it's linear open-world'ish, but so frustrating to play in. The city part is so cluttered with random stuff and rubbish that it makes your eyes bleed. The desert is far from being good too (+f so many dark areas). The last level is just lazy on so many levels. When you have to find some items in order to progress the level - they will always be at the end of the map. You kill hundreds of enemies of the same type by going there and when you pick that item - another sh|tload of them spawns on your way back... All the fights consist of spamming the same enemies over and over again. Most of the time (like 95%) is like this: Kill 20 enemies of this type, then 20 enemies of other type, and what the hell - here is another 50 of them!.. The last level takes this formula and quadruples it three times. If you play it - you will understand what I mean.  Enemies. I always hated the Skeletons in all of the Serious Sam games, they are just frustrating. But this game makes even more of these kind of enemies. Skeletons, time-stopping Witch-Brides and Space Monkeys - are the absolute worst enemies in FPS history. There is no joy in playing vs those things. I literally just skipped all those monkeys. I think this decision saved me a year of my human life. Very tedious gameplay (especially the last level). This game is like a considerably worst version of Doom (2016).Pros: The "feel" of the weapons is cool. SS3 is one of those games where playing with the headphones will help you greatly (mostly because of kamikazes). Not an easy game. I played it on normal difficulty and it was quite challenging at times. Great amount of weapons. And you will need every single one.As for the last boss - it only looks dangerous, but it's very easy and can be killed very, very quickly. I had much more trouble with those Demonic beasts (Khnums) than him during the playthrough.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												As an "old" FPS player who played quite a bit of Quake and Quakeworld back in the day, I really enjoyed Serious Sam 3: BFE. It is very satisfying to come home after a day's work and just start mowing down endless waves of enemies with whatever weapon you have, until it runs out... while running backwards... and evading Kleer Skeletons...The game gradually increases in difficulty. The first few maps are not that hard and slowly introduce you to the story, world, enemies and weapons, but later on it gets hard. It even got to a point where after trying the same part many, many times I considered cheating. In the end I didn't and I was able to pass it after some more tries. And this was on Normal difficulty...This is nowhere near a casual FPS where you just hold the fire button until everything is dead. It really pushes your senses and reflexes while fighting the various types of enemies. You need to localize and prioritize the enemies, keep an eye on your health and ammo, move, strafe, aim and fire.If you like fast paced FPS action with a bit of humor, Serious Sam 3: BFE is definately a game you need to play!

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												This is the game.Serious Sam 3: BFE (Before First Encounter)The prequel to one of the best games on the planet so far.Follow Sam 'Serious' Stone on his journey through future Egypt, as Sam shoots, explodes, bludgeons & even tear his enemies to shreds with his bare hands.This game features intense skill-based combat against intelligent AI who will get faster, smarter and as a result more dangerous.Beat the game on Serious difficulty? You should try MENTAL difficulty argueable one of the most difficult difficulties in gaming so far. Enemies won't only be smart they'll also turn invisable for several seconds & re-appear making the already hard game almost crippling.If you are not able to handle the difficulty don't fret you can set the game to "Tourist" difficult in-order to experience the game's story line & fun game mechanicsAnother thing worth mentioning is every weapon in the game is satisfying to use even the little pistol you fire has a bit of "Umph" to it as you fire it, some weapons such as the Double Barrel Shotgun work well on enemies like Kleers but it's slow re-load time makes it un-reliable in fire fights where constant fire is required. The Multiplayer on the other hand is unbalanced at best, what it boils down to is: Who has the best gun, and even still it's still has some cheap shots in it.Other than that this game is up to 16 Player Co-operative mode which is insanely fun to play with freinds.This game gets a big yes from me and everyone should try it.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Initial thoughts:With it's many play styles Serious Sam 3 BFE attempts to round out a problematic old style shooting model by creating a slow crawl of enemies and occasionally mixing in waves of enemies and bosses to keep things interesting. After playing more modern shooters it was odd to see such horrible targeting lead to successful kills. Serious mode seemed far to hard (to me) and easy difficulty was just going through the motions. So go through the motions I did. The game offers a nice array of different melee kill animations depending on the enemy being attacked. It's an interesting thought to consider that you can instantly kill anything with your bare hands, but it takes 2-3 handgun bullets by alternate means.A seasoned Sam:Things end up getting a little more intense near the end of the game and even easy mode can start getting a bit trying when enemies are simply everywhere.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Initial thoughts:With it's many play styles Serious Sam 3 BFE attempts to round out a problematic old style shooting model by creating a slow crawl of enemies and occasionally mixing in waves of enemies and bosses to keep things interesting. After playing more modern shooters it was odd to see such horrible targeting lead to successful kills. Serious mode seemed far to hard (to me) and easy difficulty was just going through the motions. So go through the motions I did. The game offers a nice array of different melee kill animations depending on the enemy being attacked. It's an interesting thought to consider that you can instantly kill anything with your bare hands, but it takes 2-3 handgun bullets by alternate means.A seasoned Sam:Things end up getting a little more intense near the end of the game and even easy mode can start getting a bit trying when enemies are simply everywhere.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												I will just start off by saying that I really enjoy this game.  It is a simple fps in common with a lot of the old school style fps games such as quake, or the SS1 first encounter or second encounter. Fast gun play, hordes of enemies running at you at once, strafe shooting, fun weaponry, ability to carry all the guns at once, and no wall hugging.  For someone who grew up playing old ID and Valve games, this is just what I needed.  A breath of fresh air in the age of little skill dumb'd down shooters trying to appeal to the common denominator.  The first few levels are pretty easy, but once you get past those, the game becomes a lot more like what the old Serious Sam games were...which is a great thing! The options menu is also very impressive, many different settings to change in case you are having some strange fps or compatibility issues. Also the game has split screen coop which is great if you have a friend over and want to destroy some of Mental's aliens.All in all, if you like FPS games and would like something more frantic and fast, pick it up.  I highly recommend it.

Serious Sam 2 took place in Alien locations that contrasted the Egypt and Jungle/Arctic/Medieval maps from TFE and TSE. In general the game is fine and a necessary improvement over the HD games. But I really wish Croteam took more risks with this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2011
												If you are getting tired of the modern FPS formula, that is a two weapon limit, regenerating health, cover based shooting, etc., the Serious Sam games have always been great for taking a break. Serious Sam 3: BFE has all the old school styled FPS traits: holding an arsenal of weapons at once, fast paced projectile dodging, and exploring all the levels for any secrets you can find. It also has the frantic Serious Sam combat that makes these games so fun, with lots and lots and lots and lots and lots of enemies attacking you at the same time. It may sound unfair, but you're built like a tank, and it's a welcome change of pace from new-school's realistic-ish, combat with a couple of enemies hiding behind cover kind of gameplay. Especially when you co-op it with friends, it is a lot of fun to dodge through enemy rockets and fireballs while laying waste to hundreds of aliens.It does have it's flaws though. While this is certainly not the kind of game you play for the story, the story is very weak with too many cheesy lines for it's own good. Also, besides some execution kills you can perform on weaker enemies, it doesn't add much to the established gameplay of the other Serious Sam titles, and that's probably not really possible with an old-school styled FPS. Most unforgiveable though, the first impressions on the game are not that great, with the first two or three levels having few enemies and an overall closed in level design. Give it some time though, the levels will open up and it will start barraging you with aliens to slaughter.If you don't take yourself too seriously (pun intended) and are a bit tired of the common cover based shooting, this game is good for some fast paced, old school macho action.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												The Short - This game is good, but not nearly half as good as the original First and Second Encounters.The Long- I still have the CD's of the original games that were made way back in 2001. those were the very first First-Person shooters I had ever played, they were what got me in to FPS games. I ave played those games non-stop, and I still play them the odd time today, the re-playability of the originals is much more than BFE. Serious Sam 2 is a different story. In the old games, you got to kill numerous bad guys with different health levels, and different weapons could kill them better, or not. You had to constantly change weapons to kill different monsters before they killed you, it was a fun and addicting challenge. But Serious Sam 3:BFE is not the same, you walk in to a corridor, and 40 Beheaded Rockiteers spawn at the exact same time, and you must kill them all with one shot killing one bad guy, that's no fun.  I don't want to sound like a complete butt, but here are my thoughts on Serious Sam 3:BFE...THE GOOD: The story is neat, it takes place as a prequel to the original games. The voice actor for Sam is the same guy as back in the old days, and all the characters (Mental's monsters) are more or less the same bad guys you loved to kill in the old games.THE BAD: I didn't like the reload function. I really didn't like that you have modern weapons, like a normal boring old sub-machine gun that looks just like any other out there today. You were never able to get enough ammo for weapons such as the Minigun for it to ever be useful like it was a powerhouse back in the old games,and NECTRISA has been significantly reduced to just an information system with no real meaning to the game. Please, bring her back, let her tell Sam what to do and where to go again! In the old games she gave you updated info and back story on bad guys and such, in BFE, he does nothing.  The music is made by the same guy who made the music for all of the Serious Sam games, and it's not bad, it's a bit repetitive, but I guess that's okay.  As I said earlier, I really hated mowing down 40 bad guys at once. PLEASE bring back the old ways where I would be stuck in a room as bad guys would spawn as I killed others.Overall, it's okay. I'm rather dissapointed in it, as it did not really feel like a Serious Sam game. It's not as good as it's predecessors, I hope Croteam is able to get back in the saddle and bring back the good old fashion carnage we loved.

												This game is prequel to Serious Sam series. Basically, this is FPS with simple goal: Kill anything what moves, and stop invasion of minions serving to one bad guy named Mental... There are many, many possible choices, how to do that: From pistols, shotguns and miniguns to bare hands or even parts of your enemies. As in Serious Sam 2, his 'serious' humour is.... Not so serious at all. Playstyle is easy, so you wont be like you dont know what to press. Also, many difficulties are quite good, and last 2 (Serious and Mental) are really hardcore, nearly unbeatable.To multiplayer.. That's something different. As you join in classic deathmatch, there is quite big chance you'll get smashed, and you will need to check the maps and learn how to pwn other players. Coop version of singleplayer missions are also nice.In my opinion this game is very good deal for that price. 9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2011
												If you are getting tired of the modern FPS formula, that is a two weapon limit, regenerating health, cover based shooting, etc., the Serious Sam games have always been great for taking a break. Serious Sam 3: BFE has all the old school styled FPS traits: holding an arsenal of weapons at once, fast paced projectile dodging, and exploring all the levels for any secrets you can find. It also has the frantic Serious Sam combat that makes these games so fun, with lots and lots and lots and lots and lots of enemies attacking you at the same time. It may sound unfair, but you're built like a tank, and it's a welcome change of pace from new-school's realistic-ish, combat with a couple of enemies hiding behind cover kind of gameplay. Especially when you co-op it with friends, it is a lot of fun to dodge through enemy rockets and fireballs while laying waste to hundreds of aliens.It does have it's flaws though. While this is certainly not the kind of game you play for the story, the story is very weak with too many cheesy lines for it's own good. Also, besides some execution kills you can perform on weaker enemies, it doesn't add much to the established gameplay of the other Serious Sam titles, and that's probably not really possible with an old-school styled FPS. Most unforgiveable though, the first impressions on the game are not that great, with the first two or three levels having few enemies and an overall closed in level design. Give it some time though, the levels will open up and it will start barraging you with aliens to slaughter.If you don't take yourself too seriously (pun intended) and are a bit tired of the common cover based shooting, this game is good for some fast paced, old school macho action.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												First person shooter Doom/Quake style, lot of enemies, lot of guns, a bit of humor, big open spaces, i played the campaing on the serious difficulty, i recommend play in that difficulty, the graphics are nice but is not too well optimized because has a lot of particles effects like dust and explosion remains that will drop your frames sometimes, but its okay, is playable, have lot of modes like survival, deathmatch, capture the flag and more, the online multiplayer is almost dead, but fortunately this game has split-screen multiplayer, you can play the campaign with friends, even survival mode (wich is so ♥♥♥♥ing hard), and every mode you can play it on split-screen, thats the best thing of this game in my opinion.The optimization is not the best, but its okay for me, has a lot of options to customize the graphic quality and the performance, the game is fun, hard, and has local split-screen, only for that i will give it a 9/10, but if it wouldnt have local split-screen would be a 6/10, because playing it alone you can get easily bored and the devs should had worked on the optimization of the game, its a very exigent GPU game, and the price is high, you should wait to a discount to buy it, as i did.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												In the end I enjoyed playing this game but at the beginning it was kind of a huge disappointment and still, even after accomplishing those last epic battles which reminds me of the good old days of SS:FE and SS:SE, I feel a bit betrayed by Croteam (aka whatever is left of it today).Not only are there boring and never ending sceneries of modern egyptian backyards which are having a certain touch of CallOfPoopy-like games (in other words: american "ubersoldier" Sam fights for "freedom" in an eastern country).They even destroyed the last chance to make this game an epic and worthy sucessor of the series by making the ancient egyptian pyramids and labyrinths completely dark, poorly detailed and filled with - without any doubt - one of the WORST kind of enemy in the history of videogames: Space Monkeys, a species of ape-like creatures which fight by hiding from the player for an almost intolerable period of time and when they FINALLY decide to attack... they hide again behind one of the many stonepillars.Most of the time I missed a lot of the old enemies and some of the awesome weapons of SSSE, like the Sniper Rifle, the Laser Gatling Cannon, the Flamethrower and the Grenade Launcher (no, I dont consider the Devastator an equal alternative, this thing is just imba and boring).If you are waiting for something as simple as a Knife or just a second pistol, well, forget it. The double barreled shotgun is, like in every game, a life-saving fella though.Oh and the Syrian Mutilator? Seriously? More like "Syrian Slowly-Waste-Away-ilator". If it takes up to 5 seconds or more to kill a simple beheaded guy that thing is just a better wristwatch.Pros:Later in the game the battles get more challenging and get almost close to those of the older SS games. Even the leveldesign gets more interesting when the modern egyptian suburbs are being displaced by ancient egyptian buildings. I wish they would have done that from the very beginning.If there was a button like "neutral", I would choose that for my review.Oh and PS: This game lacks a lot of color.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
TL;DRAn oldschool FPS with hordes of aliens to annihilate.+ Intensity+ Solid mechanics+ Loads of enemies+ Vast weaponry+ Multiplayer- A bit mind-numbing in longer sessionsREVIEWSerious Sam 3: BFE is an oldschool FPS with a few modern elements here and there. This game takes the player back to the time when Quake ruled the FPS world: no health regeneration, loadouts, radar, or quest arrow. Everything one needs to begin the massive extermination of monsters are to be found somewhere in the levels. Moreover, there are tons of secret areas so keep a lookout for them.The story is very straightforward: the protagonist, Sam Stone, is on a quest to stop the Mental's invasion on Earth. The game is set in Egypt so expect a lot of sandy areas and labyrinths. The player will find a variety of weapons throughout the game: sledgehammer, pistol, shotguns, minigun, explosives, etc. Despite being oldschool overall, the game has the option to aim down sights (ADS), sprint, and manual reload*. Speaking of variety, there are many types of aliens to obliterate, ranging from kamikazes and rocketeers to gnaars and kleer skeletons. The game can be very intense and I do not recommend long sessions, for it may become a bit mind-numbing.Apart from the single player campaign, the game features a co-op (up to 16 players) campaign, survival, and PvP multiplayer. It is important to keep in mind that the more the players there are in co-op, the stronger the enemies. Survival is a mode where the players have to defend themselves from waves of aliens and the PvP multiplayer features classic modes like deathmatch, capture the flag, and so on. It relies on peer-to-peer connection so it may get very laggy.All in all, I recommend playing this game. The solid mechanics, hordes of enemies, and a wide selection of weaponry provide hours of fun, especially in the co-op mode. It also happens to be on sale fairly often.*There is an achievement for finishing the game "ol' style", meaning no sprinting, reloading, or aiming down sights.P.S. More serious reviews here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/My curation page: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/FVABot/curation

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Short version: 82%Serious Sam 3: BFE takes us back to the roots of the series with all the elements that made the First Encounter a cult classic: no-nonsense attitude with a perfect dose of nonsense humour; classic weapons from the double-barrel shotgun to the cannon; and tricky level designs filled to the brim with secrets. This game is definitely not for the CoD generation of gamers, but if you ever want to experience what an old-school FPS was like, don’t look further.Long version:Forget CoD with its corridors, 10-minute long cut scenes, infinite ammo for the only two available weapons, cover systems and magical self-healing. Serious Sam 3: Before First Encounter is an old-school shooter where the levels are non-linear and feature many hidden spots, where your cover is your armour count, where your health is replenished by walking over medkit pickups, and where your large arsenal is only limited by the amount of ammo you can find.The only modern features BFE uses are the sprint button and limited weapon magazine size– although older gamers and Serious Sam purist can play the game without these, and they are even awarded with an achievement for it. As the sub-title suggests, BFE is a prequel telling us how Sam travelled back to ancient Egypt at the beginning of First Encounter, so thankfully we can forget about the Sirian Council and all the other stupidity of Serious Sam II. The tone is quite dark– mostly emphasised by the ruined, desolate city landscapes you fight in–, and the bad action movie one-liners and humorous Easter eggs are only meant to ease the tension a little bit.In other words, BFE is a lot closer to the First Encounter than any other Serious Sam games, probably making it the second best instalment in the whole series.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Short version: 82%Serious Sam 3: BFE takes us back to the roots of the series with all the elements that made the First Encounter a cult classic: no-nonsense attitude with a perfect dose of nonsense humour; classic weapons from the double-barrel shotgun to the cannon; and tricky level designs filled to the brim with secrets. This game is definitely not for the CoD generation of gamers, but if you ever want to experience what an old-school FPS was like, don’t look further.Long version:Forget CoD with its corridors, 10-minute long cut scenes, infinite ammo for the only two available weapons, cover systems and magical self-healing. Serious Sam 3: Before First Encounter is an old-school shooter where the levels are non-linear and feature many hidden spots, where your cover is your armour count, where your health is replenished by walking over medkit pickups, and where your large arsenal is only limited by the amount of ammo you can find.The only modern features BFE uses are the sprint button and limited weapon magazine size– although older gamers and Serious Sam purist can play the game without these, and they are even awarded with an achievement for it. As the sub-title suggests, BFE is a prequel telling us how Sam travelled back to ancient Egypt at the beginning of First Encounter, so thankfully we can forget about the Sirian Council and all the other stupidity of Serious Sam II. The tone is quite dark– mostly emphasised by the ruined, desolate city landscapes you fight in–, and the bad action movie one-liners and humorous Easter eggs are only meant to ease the tension a little bit.In other words, BFE is a lot closer to the First Encounter than any other Serious Sam games, probably making it the second best instalment in the whole series.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Need a game that features excessive gory kills, annoying decapitated kamikaze soldiers, cyclop aliens in which you can stick your fist in and rip out their eyes, topless harpy chicks, and a portable cannon that can slaughter hordes of enemies? The aforementioned outrageous sh!t is  all here in Serious Sam 3: BFE. It's a fine game to rush around and kill anything that walks around and attacks you. For that purpose, wield a 10 round Desert Eagle, a coachgun that can blast most enemies in one hit, a normal assault rifle, or a minigun and turn them into "Alien hamburger meat". If a gun doesn't work, then use an ancient bracelet and make enemies explode from the inside-out. Co-op is satisfying and it was very fun to play with a couple of buddies. Unlike some games, there is a "compass" in which it will inform you where and how far your pals are. This is very helpful when scouting around for hidden areas or to provide support. Once you experience SS 3 with a trusted friend, you don't ever want to go solo (again). Serious Sam 3: BFE did have some disappointing qualities. The level design is not impressive (especially for the underground ruins). Newcomers, like me, will have frustrations and tend to run around the map in circles when trying to find something to make progress. As the game progress, it will then spam large amounts of enemies. To me, this is mostly annoying and repetitive. Sure, you may more targets to eliminate but it quickly becomes unnecessary to endure. The A.I. has some bugs. A couple of enemies tend to get stuck or have troubles to choosing a target (if there are more than 2 players). Furthermore, their intelligence is mostly predictable and too easily exploited. The plot is very thin and is forgettable. Unless you're a fan of the series for a long time, it will make you confused. To make matters worse, the dialogue is "cheesy" and the stale characters are not interesting (well, save for Sam as he's serious enough to be a main character). Still, if you want a game to play with friends and fight hordes of aliens, then get SS 3 at a discount. $49.99 for the game itself is too much considering my cons.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2012
												Very fun game, worth whatever you can catch it on sale for! Nice graphics and awesome retro-shooter styled gameplay. Framerate is all over the place. Going from 30 to 60 isn't really uncommon throughout the game. Uncommon would be maintaining a consistent framerate, but if you set the graphics options correctly, you won't notice anything, other than the already pretty obvious blood and gore. Nothing really sets the game back other than it's 40€ normal price tag, and the lack of versus servers with a decent ping, though the latter isn't much of an issue because the game is made more for co-op anyway. Overall, much like the predecessors, there isn't much that can top Serious Sam 3 for balls to the wall shooting fun out there, so if you want to play a game with a bunch of friends and don't wanna think to much, this is a great option right here.Also,AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh....

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2013
												Ну, я ждал эту игру 6 лет и вот что разработчики преподнесли.Хотелось бы начать с графики. Её как я и ожидал улучшили, но одно меня огорчило. Движок Serious Engine 3.5 абсолютно кривой и его кривизна заметна. На моменте когда Сэм вырывает глаз гнаару хочется плакать, вид от 3го лица вообще лучше не включать. Если уж делать игру с кооперативом, то надо ж его до ума довести. Смотреть как твой партнёр держит оружие ладошками просто смешно и на то как Сэм передвигается сидя без слёз не взглянешь. Ну если откинуть движок и все его недочёты, то игра получилась очень крутой хоть непродолжительной, всего около 3-6 часов. Разработчикам удалось сохранить ту атмосферу которая была в предыдущих двух частях, когда на тебя бежит толпа разгневанных пришельцев и тебе ничего не остаётся, кроме того чтобы взять миниган и всех их похоронить.Саунтрэк просто сногшибательный, куча новых врагов, куча нового оружия, кооператив на 16 человек, все теже коронные фразочки Сэма, всё это подарило незабываемое удовольствие от игры.Конечно же игра не стоит своих 600 рублей, но на распрадаже по скидкам взять и поиграть с друзьями просто необходимо! Вобщем оценка моя такова 9.7 было бы 10 если бы движок доработали,а так игра крутая всем советую.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2012
												Very fun game, worth whatever you can catch it on sale for! Nice graphics and awesome retro-shooter styled gameplay. Framerate is all over the place. Going from 30 to 60 isn't really uncommon throughout the game. Uncommon would be maintaining a consistent framerate, but if you set the graphics options correctly, you won't notice anything, other than the already pretty obvious blood and gore. Nothing really sets the game back other than it's 40€ normal price tag, and the lack of versus servers with a decent ping, though the latter isn't much of an issue because the game is made more for co-op anyway. Overall, much like the predecessors, there isn't much that can top Serious Sam 3 for balls to the wall shooting fun out there, so if you want to play a game with a bunch of friends and don't wanna think to much, this is a great option right here.Also,AHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh....

Very difficult though, even on its Tourist difficulty. I recommend it if you're a diehard Serious Sam fan, otherwise you may find it kinda meh. But that's just my own assumption.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2013
												another robust, tightly-bound,♥♥♥♥♥♥fantasy sliding down into the easy to overcome guy vs tons of girls action genre, complete with a "gonzo" first-person pov camera.the strong male lead role, a rarity in this industry, is a breath of fresh air from all of the music that objectifies men i hear my coworkers listening to on the radio. however, there is more work to be done: the male character is muscular, hard working, and cool looking while doing it -- your typical booth babe.his dialogue is full of innuendos, too. it distracts serious gamers (yes, we exist :P ). but it's ignorable. we've sort of learned to just tune it out anyway.this game does make some strides for equality, though. there was one scene where sam stumbles into a dark alley and you just _know_ what follows. however, they avoided this trope. it's as if the ladies behind the game wanted to tell us "hey, men are people too." unfortunately, they couldn't keep a straight face long enough as the next scene had sam panting his way out of a sweaty scuffle, whereby he loses his shirt somehow. yeah. . . two step forward, three steps back.oh, btw, despite claims made by the devs during E3, this game does NOT pass the wallace/bechdel test.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Serious Sam 3 is an utterly ridiculous, stupid game that revels in its own ridiculous stupidity. The main character is a lunkhead. The enemies are absurd. Everything that happens is beyond the realm of anything that could be considered "art." But does that make it a bad game? No. Not by a long shot. It's actually one of the most riotously funny good times you can have on Steam. Beyond the humor and sort of ironic affability of the main character, the core gameplay is tough as nails but rewarding. All of the mechanics work almost perfectly, making the only thing contributing to your constant deaths your own incompetence. It's a fast, fun, furious kind of experience, and definitely something that you'll get a lot of mileage out of. (For my full reviews and gaming news, check out digitaldevils.net)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												Serving as a prequel to the original indie sensation, Serious Sam: The First Encounter, Serious Sam 3: BFE takes place during the Earth's final struggle against Mental's invading legions of beasts and mercenaries.The story, as it were, is pretty thin. It's the future. Mankind has gone off into space. Evil aliens are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off. Earth has been invaded. Humans are screwed. Sam is humanity's last hope. He doesn't give a damn, he's good with a gun, and high explosives are the perfect solution to most of his problems. Most of the dialogue is corny with a side helping of heavy cheese, but there are a few laughs sprinkled throughout. The game isn't afraid to poke fun at genre conventions, and Sam is more or less a self-aggrandizing caricature of the "buff dumb hero" stereotype.Most of the enemies are familiar, with headless kamikaze troopers, laser-spewing Biomechanoids and vicious Kleer skeletons returning with their familiar attacks in place. Every enemy has been redesigned to make them look more detestable and even disturbing than ever.Serious Sam 3: BFE is not a game for the faint of heart. It will challenge your resolve while it constantly pushes you back under a tidal wave of skeletons, fireballs, rockets and chaingun-wielding scorpions. Its levels can last up to an hour, its gameplay never deviates from one note, and it will cause players to thump their desks and roar with rage, but it's so much fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Serious Sam 3 takes the classic fast paced action and frantic gun selection of the early 90s and adds some nice spice from newer mechanics introduced in the modern day FPS genre.Often I found myself wrecklessly attacking my foes as death lingered just around the corner. Vast and expansive areas filled with hundreds of enemies swarming at me. Serious Sam is not only a tight shooter, but one that has some of the most impressive battles.What makes Serious Sam really work is the ability to truly fine tune your experience. You can make co-op a rather enjoyable and hiliarious shooter, or you can make it competitive and difficult, the choice is yours.Dying WILL happen. This game can be out right sinister with the tricks and situations it puts you in, and only your skills and smart thinking will get you through.However as great fun as that all is, what brings the game down is really itself. I found that often times killing enemies can get REALLY tedious and breaks are something of a must when looking to complete the game.Single player is also dull without anyone to experience the ridiculous traps and cheesy jokes and B movie dialogue.Multiplayer (Not Co-op) just feels a bit tacked on and really doesn't encompass what makes Sam, well, Sam. It can be fun for an hour or so, but I would really only play it to duke it out with some friends on a rare occasion.Also, the last level is absolutely BRUTAL, and I can't imagine doing it without infinite lives and a partner. Definitely my most fond memory of the game.Liked: - Fast- Action packed- Co-op galore Disliked:- RepetitiveOverall, what Sam 3 does is fun. It might not be perfect and often times dull, but when you get the chance for this game to shine it can really blow you away. One of my favorite Co-op games, and something I would recommend to anyone that has just a close friend, or even up to 16 cool dudes. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2013
												another robust, tightly-bound,♥♥♥♥♥♥fantasy sliding down into the easy to overcome guy vs tons of girls action genre, complete with a "gonzo" first-person pov camera.the strong male lead role, a rarity in this industry, is a breath of fresh air from all of the music that objectifies men i hear my coworkers listening to on the radio. however, there is more work to be done: the male character is muscular, hard working, and cool looking while doing it -- your typical booth babe.his dialogue is full of innuendos, too. it distracts serious gamers (yes, we exist :P ). but it's ignorable. we've sort of learned to just tune it out anyway.this game does make some strides for equality, though. there was one scene where sam stumbles into a dark alley and you just _know_ what follows. however, they avoided this trope. it's as if the ladies behind the game wanted to tell us "hey, men are people too." unfortunately, they couldn't keep a straight face long enough as the next scene had sam panting his way out of a sweaty scuffle, whereby he loses his shirt somehow. yeah. . . two step forward, three steps back.oh, btw, despite claims made by the devs during E3, this game does NOT pass the wallace/bechdel test.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
												Serious Sam 3 takes the classic fast paced action and frantic gun selection of the early 90s and adds some nice spice from newer mechanics introduced in the modern day FPS genre.Often I found myself wrecklessly attacking my foes as death lingered just around the corner. Vast and expansive areas filled with hundreds of enemies swarming at me. Serious Sam is not only a tight shooter, but one that has some of the most impressive battles.What makes Serious Sam really work is the ability to truly fine tune your experience. You can make co-op a rather enjoyable and hiliarious shooter, or you can make it competitive and difficult, the choice is yours.Dying WILL happen. This game can be out right sinister with the tricks and situations it puts you in, and only your skills and smart thinking will get you through.However as great fun as that all is, what brings the game down is really itself. I found that often times killing enemies can get REALLY tedious and breaks are something of a must when looking to complete the game.Single player is also dull without anyone to experience the ridiculous traps and cheesy jokes and B movie dialogue.Multiplayer (Not Co-op) just feels a bit tacked on and really doesn't encompass what makes Sam, well, Sam. It can be fun for an hour or so, but I would really only play it to duke it out with some friends on a rare occasion.Also, the last level is absolutely BRUTAL, and I can't imagine doing it without infinite lives and a partner. Definitely my most fond memory of the game.Liked: - Fast- Action packed- Co-op galore Disliked:- RepetitiveOverall, what Sam 3 does is fun. It might not be perfect and often times dull, but when you get the chance for this game to shine it can really blow you away. One of my favorite Co-op games, and something I would recommend to anyone that has just a close friend, or even up to 16 cool dudes. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												So many great homages to classic First Person Shooters have come out recently, with Shadow Warrior, Hard Reset, Wolfenstein: The New Order, Rise of The Triad etc... So, what makes Serious Sam 3 stand out from the rest? Well, here are a few reasons: This game is perfect for playing with a friend. The whole game of Serious Sam revolves around you plaing in huge, open-ended enviornments, mowing down wave after wave of literally hundreds of enemies. Playing by yourself is intense, challenging, and down-right panic enducing. With a friend, the intensity is doubled, and the fun factor just shoots through the roof. Trying to separate the waves of enemies into two different targets is really challenging, and it feels even more satisfying when you've got a buddy. The game's also down-right hilarious. The developers and writers knew what kind of game they were making, and they don't take themselves seriously at all. The game rags on itself, common action movie tropes, practically anything related to action movies in general. The weapons are just straight-up badass. They even have a double-barreled shotgun (DooM's famous "Super Shotgun") that feels just like the classic iteration. Some of the weapons are down-right wacky - like the canonball launcher, which literally flattens hundreds of enemies at a time. The gunplay feels solid, and you feel like you can dole out some serious damage-- a thing that's lacking from a lot of modern-day FPS. The amount of customization in the PC version is stellar, too. You can honestly get lost in the graphics settings menu. Seriously, more PC games need to take a hint from Croteam and allow this lush, rich level of customization options.I love classic First Person Shooters quite a bit, and I guess that's why I'm even more happy with this product. I'll be putting tons of hours into it before DooM comes out. I also highly recommend you check out the other games listed at the top of my review, but pick this one up first and go blow up some monsters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Let me preface this by saying only one thing: If you are used to easy games, then stay very far away. VERY far away. With that being said...Serious Sam 3: BFE is set a little bit before the original in the series, and has some different mechanics from the pure run'n gun originals that preceed it. Tweaks such as a dedicated sprint button, and *gasp* reloading. But the core mechanics are still the same as they always were: Kill anything that moves. The story of the game is quite a bit below average, aping the Call of Duty series thinly in the cutscenes with a touch of "serious" humor to go along with it, but for the most part, it can be ignored almost entirely, as it doesn't really add much to the overall mythos of the series. Wait.. did I just seriously say that? Though I will admit that the cutscenes involoving the reveal of bosses and such are extremely well done, and of course, the voice acting is... "serious."Graphics of the game are a treat to behold in all their glory, especially on decent systems, and despite the sheer number of enemies you face at one time, there isn't usually much slowdown to be had here. The art style has shifted to a more realistic approach, unlike earlier games in the series, which used a somewhat toned down cartoony approach to the visuals. Not an unpleasant look overall, but it might infuriate the fans of the older games.At the heart of it all, it's a run-n-gun shooter, much in the line of the legendary Quake and Doom, only amped up to the 'nth degree with literally thousands of enemies to shoot. Thanks to that, the game becomes brutally difficult, mainly due to the sheer numbers of enemies that you have to deal with at any one time. I've seen as many as 100 enemies coming at me at the same time. Are the enemies intelligent? No, thankfully. Because if they were, it would be truly impossible to beat them. Instead, they run straight for you, for the most part. Granted, there are some that have a bit of variety in their attack patterns, forcing you to shift your strategy mid-battle on a regular basis, but overall, they just have one thing to do: kill you. However, due to the variety of enemies, and the differing requirements to kill them, it NEVER gets boring. This is one of those games that every weapon is good for something, even the lowly sledgehammer gets some use, even in late game. Learning what works best for each situation becomes a part of your strategy, as each weapon has unique qualities and uses.Is this game "serious" enough to stand on the giants shoulders of the genre? Close. The brutal difficulty is the main thing that stands in the way of it being considered, in my opinion, the best of the series. One other thing...it has a serious sense of humor. Seriously.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Here's a very honest review:The game starts out with a massive wow! The guns are awesome, the humour is amazing, the boss battles are satisfying, the level design is old school. What more could you possibly want? Sadly, the game has its downfalls, as follows:~Gameplay becomes very repetitive after about 6 missions, and I found myself cheating through the last few.~The game is slightly unoptimized and frame drops are imminent.~No one online so expect only singleplayer, unless you've got buddies to play withI can't seem to get enough of the oldschool level design vibe where you find yourself running around the whole level, trying to find the exit. Sadly, the terrain gets repetitive since 90% of the missions are outside in large open spaces.Verdict:It's not worth $39.99, so pick it up if it's on sale, and if you like unrealistic old school shooters of course.Did you know?Serious Sam 3: BFE was made on the same engine as The Talos Principle?

content:
Posted: January 23
												Gameplay is frickin addictive and the guns are fun. It is the best Serious Sam game in my opinion. The only downside to this game is probably the reload mechanci which some people may not like, but I don't mind it. The sprint mechanic works perfectly for this type of game, though it looks weird and not "AAA" like, if that makes sense. You can "stutter sprint" in this game, and that's a mechanic you will have to use at "hard" or higher difficulties to get through the game. Game overall looks weird as it tries to put on a realistic setting and perhaps that is its primary drawback, but mechanically the game improves on the previous Sam games as a sequel should. Great game and a must own. A lot of challenge and fun to be had here.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Probably one of the best Serious Sam games in the series in my opinion. The sprint option in the game is great for dodging those kamikazes and kleers left and right. The melee option now makes the game even more gory than it used to be. Aim down sights is kind of cool, but somewhat useless since it just slows you down and only increases accuracy by a small percentage. It would be nice if the lasergun wasn't an easter egg and was an actual gun that was meant to be used ingame. Same thing with the sniper. Two of my favorite weapons from the old games aside from the minigun and cannon. Another note, this is possibly one of the only Serious Sam games without the serious bomb to nuke enemies, but the game makes up for it with the new features to help you with escaping and retreating to ammo and armor. All in all, my favorite game in the series and can't wait for the next installment where we get to possibly see Mental's ugly face.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2013
												I've always been fond of fast pace shooters but I haven't really played any in the last 5 or 8 years. This game brought back my love for them in new astounding ways.This game isn't something you buy for a story. The story is there all the way to the end but it's truly there to pave the way to killing thousands of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ alien monsters. Although I did enjoy the story but this is not a game to get if you want to delve into a deep story.The graphics were the first thing that spoke to me. It has serious character and is beautiful when you crank the settings out to maximum serious pwnage. You can tell it's a PC dominant game just by how many graphical settings you can tweak in-game. I absolutely love this aspect of the game. Here's where the juicy part comes in. The gameplay. This is by far the most fun I've experienced in a video game in years as far as gameplay is concerned. From the very intro I fell in love with the mechanics of ripping monsters to nothingness in a pile of red blood splattering everywhere to your screen and surroundings. Plenty of guns and plenty of serious ways to decimate your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly enemy. There's plenty of enemy variety that you will encounter in Serious Sam 3 and I love em' all (except the skeletal things). Buy this game for the gameplay cause it's rememberable and the most fun you can experience in fast paced shoot em' up while running gameplay. It's nonstop fun really. The best part about it is how much blood and gore flashes around while you kill the enemies in different ways. I was looking for a game with great blood effects and this game is top notch in that regard.The sounds in the game were also great. All the weapons and guns had their own unique tune and were a great part of the atmosphere. The music itself was good and fit the egyptian setting quite well. The best part of the music though is definitely the heavy metal music they incorporate during certain sequences. There's not much like entering a magnificent boss battle and starting with hard rocking music to give you a rush of adrenaline. You don't even need music to get an adrenaline rush in this game but it definitely succeeds in amplifying it.The map design is something I definitely enjoyed. All the levels were unique to themselves and offered much to love. The start of the game is much smaller and linear though. After you pass the first few levels though the game begins to open up massively giving you giant environments to fight. So if you don't like small maps don't fret, the game opens up to serious levels only a few levels in. Personally I liked the smaller sections as much as I liked the large ones. As far as the bad things about the game I can't say too much on that regard. The animations at times are a bit lacking but I hardly notice it when I have a rush of Kamikazi's running towards me ready to explode on impact. During cutscenes the lip animation also lacks but honestly it's not something I cared about cause I loved the overly cliche dialogue. Simply put this is a very special game for me that I had a total blast to finish. Everything from Serious Sam's one liners, graphics, gameplay, and music were absolutely perfect. Do yourself a favor and buy it cause on sale it's fairly cheap.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Serious Same 3: BFE takes everything you love about the original Serious Sam and adds some modern touches to the formula. I really like the pacing of this game. In the first Serious Sam, they throw a ton of weapons at you in a short period of time. Usually, you go in order from the best weapon to the worst in terms of power while fighting enemies until you run out of ammo. In SS3:BFE, they give you a weapon and you don't pick up another one for a longer time period, which means you understand the use of each weapon as you go through the game. Each weapon seems to have better uses for different situations. As always, the multiplayer is top notch and really fun with more players.

												SERIOUS PROBLEMS: movement in the newest serious engine feels like role-playing diarrhearocket launcher made redundantlacks previous games' level design charm, realistic enemies are cool, realistic worlds can be quite the snoreseriously obnoxious swearingPOSITIVE CHANGES:more lore and closure without hurting future titles' potentialsprinting + iron sights = immersion + blissnew iconic "melee" weapons and "finishers"someone at croteam picked up on the best song in the series and made sure everyone who tried out the survival mode knew about it toodid i mention the survival mode? difficult but oh so rewarding. Serious Sam has always had an arcade spin on it and this mode grabs that notion by the balls by impaling them on byros and flashing them at school kidsIt's good that croteam backed off on what they scared customers away with during ss2, but they've got a bit of recoil to deal with. I have to reccomend Serious Sam : The Second Encounter HD before anything else as of 2015.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												If you want a classic thowback to the good old days of old first person shooters in the form of better graphics then this is definitely for you. The Serious Sam series has been widely known to feature large and explorable areas filled with secrets and possibly easter eggs unlike most other shooters out there.Singleplayer:Story is honestly a bit crap and boring but this is outweighed by the fantastic gameplay. Tons of difficulty levels to test your skill. Tons of awesome and badass sountracks to listen to while you're killing hordes of enemies. Good level design at parts and very detailed and believable atmosphere and enivroment. Cool enemies with strengths and weaknesses. Overall singleplayer is pretty good.Multiplayer:Awesome, It's much more fun to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up with your friends than singleplayer. Play Co-Op through the singleplayer campaign. Or make the last stand in Survival trying to beat your highscore. Only problem with multiplayer is that theres not many servers anymore since this game was made a while ago :(. I've played countless hours with friends and what not in a very fun multiplayer mode.Modable Version:Very fun to see what people have come up with on the workshop. Only downside is that you can't play with other people unless they have the same mod(s) as you do.This game also can be poorly designed at certain parts. Some places where you were not meant to go can actually be found by exploiting the partially broken sandwhale mapping and the small edges that can be stood upon and jumped from and to another platform. The last level in my opinion was very very tedious, I'm sure you see what I mean if you have played this before. The final boss is a little dissapointing in my honesty and hoped it would be a little harder.8.6/10 highly reccomended for all you FPS fans out there, not the best game...but can be a fun classic, especially with friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Serious Sam in all his glory. The story is decent, the graphics are pretty awesome but more importantly the gameplay is fun. Hordes upon hordes of crazier than crazy enemies running right at you in an attempt to do the impossible: kill Serious Sam. The game is fairly difficult on the default setting, making it a nice challenge. Just get through the first few levels and you'll start seeing the old school shooter that this game really is. The only issue I could mention is the length and perhaps the pacing. The single player campaign takes about 10-12 hours - and the first few hours are very slow, compared to the rest. Playing through the game on different difficulties could make it last longer and there is a survival mode, not to mention multiplayer. It's a solid game altogether, especially if you're a fan of the series. Last but not least...It's time to get serious!

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												A fun, medium length romp through the deserts of Egypt as lacking in plot as it is in facial animations. This is made up for and then some by the sheer unbridled awesomeness of its combat. Huge hordes of enemies on even bigger maps with an even larger arsenal to shred everything that stands in your path. My only real major gripe is the final level, exluding the (suitably awesome, though initially confusing) final boss. While it had its own inhumanly large hordes of enemies, most of the level took place in a shadowy canyon. Tacking on a washed-out color filter and you get hordes that are 85% silhouettes, which is a surprisngly off putting, have spent the entire rest of the game watching your enemies explode into meaty chunks amidst a cloud of red mist. To top it all off, the game, for me at least, lagged heavily throughout most of the final level.Having said that, Serious Sam 3: BFE is still a good game and the only one in my library to rival the Saints Row series for stupid, over-the-top, but ultimately satisfying fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
 Recommended for Hardcore Gamers This game falls short compared to its predecessors, it is barely recommendable. It is still a unique gem though. Cons: - Every map has the same style: Egypt, sand, sand, and sand. Oh and a pyramid and a house.. on sand. There are a few moments where it takes a break from sand listed in the pros.- Most enemies are tough and tedious, and at times ridiculous. Half of the game (exaggeration) is struggling to survive against hordes of skeletons leaping at you while you move in circles shooting a shotgun round every 2 seconds.- Obnoxious sound from the "AHHHHHHH" enemies. It was fun for the first few minutes but, I don't even want to think about it.- The beginning of the game is very slow paced. Pros: - Has scary environments (mostly inside the dark tombs) and in some levels I was jumping in my chair from some un-intended jump scares. - Has breathtaking moments. There are about 2 parts of the game where you aren't in sand, instead you were in a   futuristic area  and that's probably why they were so breathtaking. But those 2 moments didn't last very long, sadly.- Trying to figure out how to counter the enemies. All attacks from enemies are dodge-able. What weapon should I use on that enemy? What do I do to counter that enemy's attacks? Should I run or can I fight it? Etc.- Enemy and weapon diversity, some enemies have cool abilities and you have a big arsenal to choose from.- Mostly destroy-able maps. Large scale battles and boss fights are a lot cooler when trees and walls are being blasted down. - The Storyline. Even though it was cheesy, it was still classic and didn't downgrade the game. - Special effects. People complain about the sand flying into the air upon being shot or blown up and being unable to see, but that adds to the realism and horror factor.- Alien FX Support. Keyboard is green at high HP, and it flashes red when taking damage. Medium HP it's yellow and low HP it's red.  So if you don't like challenging games that will make you angry at times, this isn't for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												Serious Sam afficionados would expect from a Serious Sam game to be about big open arenas with hundred of enemies spawning in it and a lot of big weapons to counter that. After all, the tutorial of Serious sam 1 had more than 500 enemies in it.Well, for the first 4 levels, this game doesn't deliver that. Instead, we're in cluttered city, with small weapons, and very few enemies (about 150-200 per level). It seems like the developpers wanted to introduce the world of Serious Sam slowly for people who are more used to modern games such as Call of Duty. It does deliver some hard fights because you don't have many weapons, but it's not that fun after a whileHowever, if you manage to get over that first phase, you will finally get your rocket launcher at the end of level 4, and your first big arena at the end of level 5. And then, you will finally get the Serious Sam game you were looking for. The big arenas are back, with tons of ammo (sometimes even boxes of infinite ammo) for you to be able to use the biggest and most badass weapons without a second thought. Waves of enemies will come, and you will mercilessly mow them down.More over, that second part of the game is cleverly designed. Instead of just being endless slaughter after endless slaughter, the game manages to provide some variety. For example, it will often alternate between the big open arenas where you can be as badass as you want, and some underground, claustrophobic corridors, where the limited vision offered by your flashlight will make you a prey. There are also others set pieces that I will not spoil for you. Suffice to say that once the game finally start rolling, it's hard to put down, it does a lot of stuff very well, up to the final level, which is utterly insane, and a great conclusion to the game.On the technical side, the Serious Sam 3 engine is extremely impressive, it manages to have dozens of enemies on the screen at the time, while looking gorgeous, and also have destructible terrain. If you or one of the enemy uses rockets, or C4, you will be able to blow up almost any obstacle, for example to remove the cover of an enemy, or to help give you a better line of sight on far away enemies. Finally, I want to give a mentions to the soundtrack which is fantastic, and accompagnies the game extremely well. Big thumbs up for that.So my final word is easy : buy this game, get over the first four levels even if you're not that happy with them, and you will be rewarded by a great game of utter mayhem and joyous use of rocket launcher.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Croteam has done it again!PROS--Smooth as hell gameplay-Huge Multiplayer-Original components as well as new additions to game mechanics-Great story-WorkshopCONS--Terrible cutscenes-Unecessary charactersOVERVIEW-This game has almost everything right. Gameplay is fluid and fresh and originates to the old mechanics perfectly. Multiplayer still goes big and bold, with Story Co-Op, Deathmatch and the new Survival mode. Workshop compatability allows for mods and maps, which give the game endless hours of fun, besides the fact that people hardly ever release maps or mods. My only problems relate to the story. Don't get me wrong, the story is freakin awesome and keeps a lot of the same elements from the classics. Only problem I have is the cutscenes and characters. Every time the characters show up, they either die after that cutscene or you only get to see them in another cutscene, that you're not involved in, where they die. Every character just arrives to die. It's pointless and doesn't enrich the story in any way. Besides these cons, the game itself is amazingly fun and has a pretty damn high replay value. 420/360 would smoke again

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Serious Same 3: BFE takes everything you love about the original Serious Sam and adds some modern touches to the formula. I really like the pacing of this game. In the first Serious Sam, they throw a ton of weapons at you in a short period of time. Usually, you go in order from the best weapon to the worst in terms of power while fighting enemies until you run out of ammo. In SS3:BFE, they give you a weapon and you don't pick up another one for a longer time period, which means you understand the use of each weapon as you go through the game. Each weapon seems to have better uses for different situations. As always, the multiplayer is top notch and really fun with more players.

												Most of the things they've introduced anew are kind of bad, like weapon reloading, and sprinting while unable to use your weapon, rather than Sam just running that fast all the time. Melee kills are kind of neat once, but you just don't have time for them by the point the game has ramped up to a proper Serious level.It doesn't matter. It's still Sam. Soon the trappings of more modern shooters fall away and leave you with the familiar old tools, weaving your way through a herd of Kleer while trying to deal with the approaching gigantic horror before it steps on you. It doesn't really progress the series in any way but graphically (the plot has gone backwards again), but it can get away with being another iteration of the solid fast-and-fluid FPS and leave you grinning from the adrenaline.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Coming from my FAVORITE videogame series of all time! Serious Sam 3: BFE shows me a different perspective of how this was all started. The mechanics are fairly the same as for the others in the official series campaign (excluding the indie games) just run, gun, blow up, and basically 'shoot everything that moves!' Along with the (not entirely rspected) modernized mechanics for sprinting, which is extremely helpful in some cases of survivalbility. Aiming sights, which is kind of dumb having to do that because the original games had their guns automatically pinpoint accurate. And the melee which is a nice touch for me, giving more killing varieties. The levels for this game are MASSIVE and have secrets scattered about everywhere, but I am not going to complain how people think the level designs are 'linear.' Just to note that the classic games had linearity of their own perspective, but not big. The music ambience is really soothing, battle music fits my tastes, and boss music gives a big sense of adrenaline for me. The artstyle for me is decent, I do enjoy its 'semi-realism' approach; but I go for the classic's artstyle which had more cartoonish aspects to it. The weapons are still as devastating as ever. The enemy count is HUGE and there are some new variety of enemies now, though not much more, but some. The DLC (Jewel of the Nile) topped the icing, bringing what fans more wanted.My overall verdict: Buy it!
