number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2012
												Serious Sam 3 is a glorious nod back to the waves of attacking enemies that faced you in the original Doom games. Nothing towards the end of 2011 (in FPS terms) even comes close to the manic reload & fire action of SS3. Little story. Hardly any background filler - pretty much zero character progression.But do we care? Not at all. SS3 is all about survival. With completely OTT weaponry taking on increasingly OTT enemies - it's a great cerebral diversion. No planning ahead. No kit customisations in order to make sure you get the job done. Simply load up and go in with all barrels blazing.SS3 is built upon the new Serious Engine 3.5 as well, meaning with all the bells & whistles turned on, it is a graphically sumptuous game to look at. Is it very scalable too, so even low end PCs could happily run SS3 with some options reduced or disabled.Great effort, great game.... 7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Serious Sam 3 BFE is actually a prequel of the previous Serious Sam games, with BFE meaning Before First Encounter. You’ll see a lot of similarities between the main character Sam Stone, and Duke Nukem, the other super macho hero from around the same gaming era. The games are quite different though. Where Duke Nukem Forever (the latest Duke game) tried to model itself as a modern shooter, Serious Sam 3 sticks to its roots of being a You vs 10000 enemies type horde shooter. Each enemy has just enough life that you need to focus your fire on them as a hundred others come running at you. You’ll spend a lot of the game running backwards as you lay down the fire.Unlike the previous Serious Sam games (First Encounter, Second Encounter, Serious Sam 2) BFE takes place in the future. Unfortunately, in this future the Earth has been overrun by aliens and the whole game occurs in devastated cities and ancient Egyptian ruins. Serious Sam 3’s story is mostly about how Sam needs to activate and use an ancient Sirian (alien) device called the Time Lock, which will allow him to go back in time and prevent the alien invasion.  There isn’t really a primary antagonist for the game, although Sam’s old enemy Mental (the boss in previous games) is mentioned as being the leader of the aliens. BFE is an old school first person shooter with loads of health/ammo pickups, loads of enemies, and a bunch of big♥♥♥♥♥bosses to fight. The sheer number of enemies practically guarantees that you take damage in every engagement, but there’s so much health and armor laying around that the game is a huge survival match.  This is one of those games where I would actually recommend people to play on one of the easier difficulties the first time through. There’s a lot of stress relief to be found in blowing up hundreds of enemies with a wide assortment of weapons. Get used to holding down the trigger button as you back up and sidestep enemies charging after you. The game also has a ton of secrets to find, generally health/ammo/weapons. These are the old school secrets where you actually have to look for them by climbing over walls or busting through barricades. In a lot of modern games the secrets are just out of the way like in a dead end corridor or under a staircase. This is not the case in Serious Sam 3. You can play through this whole game and only find about 5 out of 100+ secrets unless you know what you’re looking for. Pros:+While the story is forgettable, the game has pretty nice graphics with a bunch of weapons to choose from. The thousands of enemies you face means that you’re going to really in the action most of the time. +There actually seem to still be multiplayer servers running. The game’s co-op mode is pretty fun.+Giant bosses! Cons:-Yes, the game can be brainless at times, but that’s part of its charm . Do note however, that there is some annoying puzzle solving to be done in the game. It’s usually about finding keys to locked doors or opening wall panels to get out of underground chambers.-Even on easy mode the game can be difficult (for impatient people). The difficulty setting doesn’t seem to affect the number of enemies you face, just how much life and damage dealing power they have. Near the end there are sections with infinite rocket launcher ammo and seemingly thousands of enemies rushing you.Overall, Serious Sam 3 is a fun game, and if you enjoyed the previous ones you’ll like the modern update. If you’ve only played Serious Sam 2, note that part 2 is quite different from the others in the series (more focused on humor). Serious Sam 3 is more focused on big guns mowing down aliens.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												I've always been a fan of the old school run-gun-fun style of first-person shooters compared to call of duty or battlefield and Serious Sam 3 BFE is an excellent call-back to that era of gaming. The fastest way to describe it would be to call it the first Serious Sam game wearing the mask of a modern FPS. The level design varies from the ruins of Cairo to ancient Egyptian cities but all feature three main things. Large open ares, massive hordes and big damm guns. Theres quite a bit of variation in enemies and weapons to keep it from getting repetitive but having said this, some enemy attacks can become very annoying, especially when you've just grabbed a minigun are in the zone. Overall, it's a very enjoyable game with some funny dialogue and satisfying gameplay.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Serious Sam 3 BFE is actually a prequel of the previous Serious Sam games, with BFE meaning Before First Encounter. You’ll see a lot of similarities between the main character Sam Stone, and Duke Nukem, the other super macho hero from around the same gaming era. The games are quite different though. Where Duke Nukem Forever (the latest Duke game) tried to model itself as a modern shooter, Serious Sam 3 sticks to its roots of being a You vs 10000 enemies type horde shooter. Each enemy has just enough life that you need to focus your fire on them as a hundred others come running at you. You’ll spend a lot of the game running backwards as you lay down the fire.Unlike the previous Serious Sam games (First Encounter, Second Encounter, Serious Sam 2) BFE takes place in the future. Unfortunately, in this future the Earth has been overrun by aliens and the whole game occurs in devastated cities and ancient Egyptian ruins. Serious Sam 3’s story is mostly about how Sam needs to activate and use an ancient Sirian (alien) device called the Time Lock, which will allow him to go back in time and prevent the alien invasion.  There isn’t really a primary antagonist for the game, although Sam’s old enemy Mental (the boss in previous games) is mentioned as being the leader of the aliens. BFE is an old school first person shooter with loads of health/ammo pickups, loads of enemies, and a bunch of big♥♥♥♥♥bosses to fight. The sheer number of enemies practically guarantees that you take damage in every engagement, but there’s so much health and armor laying around that the game is a huge survival match.  This is one of those games where I would actually recommend people to play on one of the easier difficulties the first time through. There’s a lot of stress relief to be found in blowing up hundreds of enemies with a wide assortment of weapons. Get used to holding down the trigger button as you back up and sidestep enemies charging after you. The game also has a ton of secrets to find, generally health/ammo/weapons. These are the old school secrets where you actually have to look for them by climbing over walls or busting through barricades. In a lot of modern games the secrets are just out of the way like in a dead end corridor or under a staircase. This is not the case in Serious Sam 3. You can play through this whole game and only find about 5 out of 100+ secrets unless you know what you’re looking for. Pros:+While the story is forgettable, the game has pretty nice graphics with a bunch of weapons to choose from. The thousands of enemies you face means that you’re going to really in the action most of the time. +There actually seem to still be multiplayer servers running. The game’s co-op mode is pretty fun.+Giant bosses! Cons:-Yes, the game can be brainless at times, but that’s part of its charm . Do note however, that there is some annoying puzzle solving to be done in the game. It’s usually about finding keys to locked doors or opening wall panels to get out of underground chambers.-Even on easy mode the game can be difficult (for impatient people). The difficulty setting doesn’t seem to affect the number of enemies you face, just how much life and damage dealing power they have. Near the end there are sections with infinite rocket launcher ammo and seemingly thousands of enemies rushing you.Overall, Serious Sam 3 is a fun game, and if you enjoyed the previous ones you’ll like the modern update. If you’ve only played Serious Sam 2, note that part 2 is quite different from the others in the series (more focused on humor). Serious Sam 3 is more focused on big guns mowing down aliens.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Serious Sam 3 BFE. Seriously Serious Savagery From Sam's Shotgun Shells.Genre: FPS Large-Scale Linear Arena Shooter. Single, Co-Op & Multiplayer. Modding Support.Developed & Published by: Croteam & Devolver DigitalPlatform: Windows, Mac and Linux.DRM: SteamWorks.Business Model: Single Purchase + Expansion DLCCopy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsSerious Sam 3 BFG (as well as the rest of the entries) are all about Sam trying to save Earth from a never ending army of alien monsters led by a mysterious overlord named "Mental". The player is tasked with running through arena after arena where they must kill all the enemies in order to keep progressing. There's a variety of weapons to choose from including a sledgehammer, double-barreled shotgun, RPG launcher, alien laser weapon all the way up to a literal cannon. The challenge isn't the individual enemies themselves but the constant torrential downpour of them as they charge at you. Add enemies with ranged attacks, a giant open area where they can come at you from all sides and you've got a recipe for an intense experience of destruction and survival. The enemy AI is brain dead as they'll repeat the same attack patterns over and over again. What makes them dangerous the sheer number of them and how much they'll hurt if they land a shot. Most enemies are dangerous to touch, which makes using the hammer as you go later into the game a dicey affair. Not impossible and a hell of a lot of fun, but dicey. As such, you'll need to keep moving and strafing to the left or right to dodge their attacks. There are a range of enemies from yelling beheaded kamikazes and harpies to acid throwing giant spiders and two-legged mechanoids bristling with rocket launchers and lasers. When enemies are killed, there's an explosion of dust that will obfuscate the area behind them. The most aggravating enemy to me are the Kleers, these running skeleton chargers pack a punch and are difficult to avoid. So, not only do you have to keep your eyes peeled for the next enemies coming your way, you have to keep in mind any enemies you dodged/didn't kill and listen for any you may not have noticed coming your way. Fortunately for Sam, enemies telegraph themselves with loud sounds that are immediately distinguishable from the cacophony of weapons' firing. Which you'll need as some of these fights can last for a long time and it can be trying, if not exhilarating to keep up with everything.Most weapons in the game for both Sam and the enemies are projectile weapons with a few hitscan weapons including the assault rifle. Nearly all the weapons are a joy to use, even the pistol with it's somewhat weak damage. My personal favorites are the XPML21 Rocket Launcher, SBC Cannon (because badasses love cannons) and XM-214-A Minigun. I'd say my only major complaint about the combat mechanics is that it's really stingy with ammo for the higher-end weapons while providing a ton of ammo for the shotgun. There are also some enemies that have hitscan weapons that I'm not a big fan of either.I remain impressive that SS3 continues to hold up today when stacked up against the current kings of the FPS genre. The gameplay design may be simplistic at first glance, but there is a depth and purity to the chaos that helps it to remain enjoyable even five years after I started playing. Dodging and weaving through the hordes still hasn't gotten old. Even the graphics still hold up even if some minor objects in the environment look a bit questionable. And the badass soundtrack accents the action perfectly as well.Narrative TalkSS3 takes place before the events of Serious Sam: The First Encounter. Humanity is losing the war against Mental and has tasked Sam and his team with locating and protecting a scientist. This scientist believes that he has located an ancient artifact that may turn the tide of war in their favor. The Time Lock, a device that could send people back in time in order to assassinate Mental before the war ever started. What follows is a lengthy campaign where Sam has to locate the Time Lock and the generators to turn it on. Thus transporting him to the events of The First Encounter. The story is pretty simplistic with a lot of the dialogue being handled over a radio conversation with "Command" and in cutscenes. Characters don't go through any arcs, nothing really surprising happens, it's just a straight shot (with detours) to the goal of turning on the Time Lock. Certainly there's a underlying tension about how Earth is losing the war but it never really seems to get to Sam. Jewel of the Nile DLC's story is about turning on a third generator that's apparently required to turn the Time Lock on. So I guess we're supposed to assume that it was done off-screen during the main campaign. Serious Sam is an endearing character filled with one-liners and quips while maintaining a serious atmosphere about himself.  He can be a bit simple at times but it's part of his charm. This seemingly invincible soldier can get the job done. He just needs a few guns and explosives.PC Settings and Audio/VideoThe extensive options that the game provides is impressive. If you want to tweak something about Serious Sam, it'll let you. The Serious Sam Engine 3.5 shows off impressive vistas, lighting and bloody gibs galore while you fight hundreds of monsters. This shooter takes place largely in Egypt. So, expect to see plenty of sand, deserts and pyramids. Though there's the occasional town and oasis to break things up. There's even some destructible terrain thrown in at times, though the levels are largely static. The game is very well optimized and I don't recall having any maddening issues such as crashing or bugs. Even more impressive is the support of up to 16 people in co-op and multiplayer. I've always wanted to get a LAN party like that setup just to see how crazy that would be. Alas, I've never had the chance. (16 co-op isn't restricted to LAN but it probably works the best over LAN rather than Internet).Final ThoughtsSerious Sam 3: BFE remains one of my favorite FPSes to come back to every now and again.  Both the base game and the expansion DLC: Jewel of the Nile are well worth playing through even if it's only for the single player content. The multiplayer community isn't worth joining but co-op definitely is if you can get some friends involved. I have no complaints with the campaign, it's nicely paced and lengthy enough with plenty of interesting combat sections. Same goes for the DLC, though the difficulty is definitely higher than the base game. I think that Serious Sam 3 is well worth picking up even after all of these years. Go get Serious Sam 3 and prepare for War!Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												This game reminds me so much of the online MonsterHunt in the first Unreal Tournament (NOT Invasion in UT2004). The game doesn't send enemies at you in waves in arenas. No, you have to keep pushing and pushing further on the map through the enemies.Luckily, there are often places where you can take a break too. And you will want to. The fights in this game are incredibly intense. I simply had to just stop and take some deep breaths and relax abit. You find a minigun and never stop firing it for like 5 minutes, because the game just keeps throwing them at you, while you dodge chained cannonballs.The jokes could be better. I discovered this game when I played Shadow Warrior. I heard he's kinda like Duke, so I expected him to be funnier.Do be careful when playing this game for longer sessions. Dodging the rain of projectiles requires a lot of concentration and may cause headache withtin 1-2 hours.8/10 would spread democracy at 3000 freedoms per minute again.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
A Paladin’s Steam Review: Serious Sam 3 BFE. Seriously Serious Savagery From Sam's Shotgun Shells.Genre: FPS Large-Scale Linear Arena Shooter. Single, Co-Op & Multiplayer. Modding Support.Developed & Published by: Croteam & Devolver DigitalPlatform: Windows, Mac and Linux.DRM: SteamWorks.Business Model: Single Purchase + Expansion DLCCopy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsSerious Sam 3 BFG (as well as the rest of the entries) are all about Sam trying to save Earth from a never ending army of alien monsters led by a mysterious overlord named "Mental". The player is tasked with running through arena after arena where they must kill all the enemies in order to keep progressing. There's a variety of weapons to choose from including a sledgehammer, double-barreled shotgun, RPG launcher, alien laser weapon all the way up to a literal cannon. The challenge isn't the individual enemies themselves but the constant torrential downpour of them as they charge at you. Add enemies with ranged attacks, a giant open area where they can come at you from all sides and you've got a recipe for an intense experience of destruction and survival. The enemy AI is brain dead as they'll repeat the same attack patterns over and over again. What makes them dangerous the sheer number of them and how much they'll hurt if they land a shot. Most enemies are dangerous to touch, which makes using the hammer as you go later into the game a dicey affair. Not impossible and a hell of a lot of fun, but dicey. As such, you'll need to keep moving and strafing to the left or right to dodge their attacks. There are a range of enemies from yelling beheaded kamikazes and harpies to acid throwing giant spiders and two-legged mechanoids bristling with rocket launchers and lasers. When enemies are killed, there's an explosion of dust that will obfuscate the area behind them. The most aggravating enemy to me are the Kleers, these running skeleton chargers pack a punch and are difficult to avoid. So, not only do you have to keep your eyes peeled for the next enemies coming your way, you have to keep in mind any enemies you dodged/didn't kill and listen for any you may not have noticed coming your way. Fortunately for Sam, enemies telegraph themselves with loud sounds that are immediately distinguishable from the cacophony of weapons' firing. Which you'll need as some of these fights can last for a long time and it can be trying, if not exhilarating to keep up with everything.Most weapons in the game for both Sam and the enemies are projectile weapons with a few hitscan weapons including the assault rifle. Nearly all the weapons are a joy to use, even the pistol with it's somewhat weak damage. My personal favorites are the XPML21 Rocket Launcher, SBC Cannon (because badasses love cannons) and XM-214-A Minigun. I'd say my only major complaint about the combat mechanics is that it's really stingy with ammo for the higher-end weapons while providing a ton of ammo for the shotgun. There are also some enemies that have hitscan weapons that I'm not a big fan of either.I remain impressive that SS3 continues to hold up today when stacked up against the current kings of the FPS genre. The gameplay design may be simplistic at first glance, but there is a depth and purity to the chaos that helps it to remain enjoyable even five years after I started playing. Dodging and weaving through the hordes still hasn't gotten old. Even the graphics still hold up even if some minor objects in the environment look a bit questionable. And the badass soundtrack accents the action perfectly as well.Narrative TalkSS3 takes place before the events of Serious Sam: The First Encounter. Humanity is losing the war against Mental and has tasked Sam and his team with locating and protecting a scientist. This scientist believes that he has located an ancient artifact that may turn the tide of war in their favor. The Time Lock, a device that could send people back in time in order to assassinate Mental before the war ever started. What follows is a lengthy campaign where Sam has to locate the Time Lock and the generators to turn it on. Thus transporting him to the events of The First Encounter. The story is pretty simplistic with a lot of the dialogue being handled over a radio conversation with "Command" and in cutscenes. Characters don't go through any arcs, nothing really surprising happens, it's just a straight shot (with detours) to the goal of turning on the Time Lock. Certainly there's a underlying tension about how Earth is losing the war but it never really seems to get to Sam. Jewel of the Nile DLC's story is about turning on a third generator that's apparently required to turn the Time Lock on. So I guess we're supposed to assume that it was done off-screen during the main campaign. Serious Sam is an endearing character filled with one-liners and quips while maintaining a serious atmosphere about himself.  He can be a bit simple at times but it's part of his charm. This seemingly invincible soldier can get the job done. He just needs a few guns and explosives.PC Settings and Audio/VideoThe extensive options that the game provides is impressive. If you want to tweak something about Serious Sam, it'll let you. The Serious Sam Engine 3.5 shows off impressive vistas, lighting and bloody gibs galore while you fight hundreds of monsters. This shooter takes place largely in Egypt. So, expect to see plenty of sand, deserts and pyramids. Though there's the occasional town and oasis to break things up. There's even some destructible terrain thrown in at times, though the levels are largely static. The game is very well optimized and I don't recall having any maddening issues such as crashing or bugs. Even more impressive is the support of up to 16 people in co-op and multiplayer. I've always wanted to get a LAN party like that setup just to see how crazy that would be. Alas, I've never had the chance. (16 co-op isn't restricted to LAN but it probably works the best over LAN rather than Internet).Final ThoughtsSerious Sam 3: BFE remains one of my favorite FPSes to come back to every now and again.  Both the base game and the expansion DLC: Jewel of the Nile are well worth playing through even if it's only for the single player content. The multiplayer community isn't worth joining but co-op definitely is if you can get some friends involved. I have no complaints with the campaign, it's nicely paced and lengthy enough with plenty of interesting combat sections. Same goes for the DLC, though the difficulty is definitely higher than the base game. I think that Serious Sam 3 is well worth picking up even after all of these years. Go get Serious Sam 3 and prepare for War!Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												It's your usual Serious Sam game, but on an engine that actually looks good instead of looking like a Unity3D game.  Expect the usual; 1000+ enemies on screen at once, 20 weapons in total, and♥♥♥♥♥♥in your pants the moment you hear "AAAAAAAHHHHHHHHHHH" Definitely worth picking up when you get the chance, provided you have at least two people to make sure they don't all focus on you 100% of the time.Also, this game may have unknowingly inspired the new Doom's "glory-kill" mechanic. :\Brief mention: this game is also the most well-optimized game you'll probably ever see from the last five years.  Performance is unreasonably good, the options menu makes Mad Max look consolized, and it's divided nicely into CPU Performance / GPU Speed / GPU Performance with five presets each.So yeah, good purchase, good use of the money I previously wasted on id's Rage and its awful engine.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game! Great Graphics, old-school run & gun gameplay, and funny one-liners. Serious Sam has got to be one of the best franchises I have ever played. Serious Sam 3 may be the perfect blend of old school and modern in a game yet. But there are a few things about this game I do not like.One of the things I do not like about this game is they changed the jumping height compared to the other games. The jumping feels odd and floaty. It is like they changed the jumping height at the last minute before they released this game so players would not jump over walls in the first few levels of the game.Another thing I do not like is the sound effects and animation for some of the weapons. The pump-action shotgun and M4 Machine gun feels and sounds under-powered. The animations are kind of lame also that doesn't display the power that the weapon very well.The reloading feature in this game is a mixed bag for me. It sometimes gets in the way of the action, but that does give the game more challenge. Would I want to disable the reloading, yes and no, but I will pass on this being a negative.BUT... You can change these negatives to positives through the Steam Workshop. You can get mods that replace the weapons sounds and animation with better ones and there is also a mod that enhances the jumping in the game to match with the previous games.Do I recommend this game? If you are into fast-paced old school FPS games, then HELL ♥♥♥♥ING YES I RECOMMEND THIS!!!!

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												It's not nearly as great as the first two games (First and Second Encounter), but it is still a decent game. If you haven't played them I would recommend getting the HD versions of said games before playing  BFE. The following will mainly be my criticism of the game since I believe most reviewers summed up the positives well enough. The begining to the game is somewhat slow and boring, accelerated only slightly by the secret more advanced weapons (if you find them), it gets better after the first 3 or 4 missions. You lose health a lot quicker in this game compared to the first two simply because a lot of the basic grunts are equipped with bullet firing human firearms which are impossible to dodge. Some of the basic grunts are still equipped with the good old futuristic guns firing slow moving projectiles from the First and Second Encounter, which could be dodged even when there were massive hales coming at you if you were skilled enough, but they appear to be in the minority. As far as I can recall (it has been a while since I last played it) certain weapons from Serious Sam The Second Encounter are missing in this game, most notably the Flamethrower and the Chainsaw. The only new weapon added, The Syrian Bracelet is largely impractical to use in combat since it takes ages to kill stuff with it and larger enemies are effectivelly impervious to it (if you have multiple people using it at the same time it is also effective against the big enemies, but is still slow to use), hence it is largely a token irrelevant addition, even if you can perform some rather nice looking executions with it. The quick melee executions while fun are too powerful, particularly early on into the game where there is a relatively low amount of enemies. It is infinitely more effective to simply snap the necks of grunts or tear away the spider's shells rather then shooting them, which gets a bit silly after you repeat it in sequence as often as you do. However as the game goes on this becomes less of an issue as it is almost impossible to use against massive hordes of enemies, without the monsters butchering you whilst you are locked into a short execution cutscene.With the exception of Ugh-Zan IV, all the "bosses" in the game are a disappointment. Most of them are really just minibosses and serve as introductions for enemies you will encounter regularly. The only other boss in the game apart from Ugh-Zan IV, which isn't a miniboss, is the Alcor class Warship, which I personally am loath to even consider a boss, since it doesn't really fight you, it just spawns an endless stream of mobs. The Jewel of the Nile DLC boss is ok despite being boring due to a lack of variation in attacks, the largest issue with him being that he is a colossal bullet sponge and as such you run out of ammunition long before he runs out of health and have to spend ages finishing him off with a pistol (which is kind of a problem considering that while his projectiles are easy enough to avoid, they kill you instantly upon contact, meaning you have no room for error).The enemy variety in the game isn't bad, albeit I feel that more new enemy types could have been added. However two of the new enemy types, the Witch Bride of Achriman and the Technopolip, are poorly designed and just a general nuissance to deal with. In the case of the technopolip, the infested helicopter is extremely hard to hit, particularly with the rocket launcher, meaning that you waste too long looking at the sky trying to line up a proper shot, whilst hordes of enemies require you to keep your eyes on the ground. What is worse its bullets cannot be dodged, meaning that you just have to hide behind cover all the time. This game isn't Call of Duty, its all about mobility and fast paced action, so why make an enemy which inhibits just that? The witch bride is even worse, particularly if there are multiple of them. This is because if you don't immediately start shooting them after they appear, (after enough damage has been dealt to them they will disappear and teleport to a new location after a delay) they will incapacitate you by slowing your movements and then levitate you slightly whilst dealing damage to you. This wouldn't be an issue in and of itself, however when you are being swarmed by a large group of enemies they will mean the death of you if you don't dispatch of them ASAP. Since they slow you down and make you levitate if you don't notice where they are and shoot them in time they will prevent you from moving meaning the other enemies will encircle you resulting in effectivelly instantaneous death. Since it is hard to notice where they are going to teleport to next when you are busy with crowds of other enemies, they far too often cause you to die in a really cheesy unsatisfying way. However by far the biggest issue I had with the game was the fact that on my PC the game suffered from quite common micro frame drops, meaning every 2 minutes or so the game would drop to 1 fps and seemingly freeze for about half a second. The game otherwise ran well, but no fixes suggested on the forums proved conducive to removing this issue. Nonetheless while annoying this didn't make the game unplayable for me. Furthermore while relatively common it doesn't seem to be a technical difficulty experienced by a majority of the player base, hence if you are looking to buy this game, it probably won't affect you.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												A generic nostalgia fake-revival game, which is a consolized first encounter, including dumb pyramids AGAIN. So, basically they removed most weapons, added some generic tacticool boring hitscans, added a lot of useless hitscan enemies and a lot of annoying hostile timewasters. In level-design they shrank everything and included captain price giving you sudden death if you go out of intended path. On top of it you now may enjoy endless pitch black onaholes infested with crab louses.At least some core gameplay is the same — you stand in the fartherst corner of the map and shoot your gun until green crosshair turns into red, or you run around getting kicked in the posterior by kleers. Also now there are press X to melee, because of course it would be there.Music is some faux-ethno annoying cymbals which is worsened by the greatest invention of all times — dynamic music (which means it randomly starts and stops, creating utter κακοφωνία right in your ears).Well at least writing is okay, and it's funny to see Sejic in the credits. It took me two and a half years to finish main campaign. SSam never was a masterpiece and this one is even more boring. Most of the game i completed little by little each time when i tested new hardware to see if my performance increased, because it run very bad on my base PC and still drops FPS on GF970SLI and i7 on sub high settings. And the settings are the best part of the whole game and have most gameplay and player agency in them. Game runs fine at UHD UWS and offers good customization of HUD etc.Oh, and christmas achievment is bugged.

content:
Posted: April 4
												Criticizing SS3 6 years later is pointless, especially with its positive rating here. But I can't turn away now that the exercise of seriousness has turned to mediocrity and tediousness.It's baffling how SS3 has almost no unique and fun secrets (wow, I've found a piece of armor around the corner... for the hundredth time!), compared to older games in the series. Too many secrets are hidden behind annoying parkour. What's more, weapon placement is not well-thought; during several starting levels you're forced to use shotguns and assault rifle, whereas in old Encounters you'd see almost all gear by the first major boss. Ammo backpacks that restore all ammo are removed to force you to look for ~S E C R E T~ ammo pick-ups. Iconic Serious Bomb is nowhere to be seen. Very few memorable skirmishes where you go all-out, and when it happens you vomit blood — the last level of this game is an insult to carefully crafted The Great Pyramid and The Grand Cathedral final levels from the classics. Overall the level design is abysmal with identical areas all over the place. Also painfully slow pitch-dark horror sections in egyptian pyramid tombs. SS3 has extremely cheap new types of enemies who are either invulnerable to certain attacks and/or can disable you from afar. On harder difficulties the game forces you to backtrack to ammo crates (ammo crates with infinite ammo in Serious Sam, it speaks for itself~), because playing without C4 is the opposite of rewarding experience. Projectile enemies are extremely accurate now even a kilometer away from you, forcing the player to use cover on harder difficulties. So much for All Man No Cover mantra.Everything in this game is a downgrade from older games. I've been repeating verb "force" again and again, because this game is a "forced" Serious Sam entry, it tryhards to be more serious than it should be. Serious Sam 2 was getting a lot of hate in its own time, but it's, in fact, a much better game than this abomination. You're better off playing First and Second Encounter HD remakes.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Seriously, this is definitely my favorite title in the series. As a diehard Doomer, I've just become a fan at last, long after the first Serious Sam released over a decade ago.The very essence is the fast and intuitional gameplay (and all its flexibility), that I hope doing the same/well for DOOM(4). You can shoot and blow up the heck outta the aliens, you can melee through without ammo, you can sprint and BE a runner all the way in this game. Of course, you still can play like an old-school Sammy without reloading or sprinting, always holding-down-trigger-non-stop, only charging and dying in glory. That style(arcade/arena) was not what I truly prefer.As for what previous Serious Sam players care, you might not feel content with the newer one, for the absence of illogical craziness its predecessors had. Serious Sam 3 did most things the 'maturer' way, you won't find too much ridiculous nonsense or anything more 'serious' than exploded Earth :)Croteam also did a great job on the third(actually not) implement itself: decent visuals, sounds, environments, progressing, acting, and the most 'serious' story EVER; everything seems quite balanced for most audiences. Aside from traditional total madness, I believe majority of FPS players may accept and enjoy the game, hardcore or not.+Pros: (or compared with the classics)chaos battles and brutal deathsequally beautiful and majestic sceneryyou can now outrun many enemies (aka skip the horde or run like hell)better item placement (prevents you from wasting time running like a cleaning robot)all your arsenal weapons work functionally better together, even the useless pistol (homage to Doom?)C4 is better than grenades, Devastator is cooler than a sniper rifle, and I'm so glad they took Serious Bomb out because I really hate how it workedmost combat maneuvers against respective foes are reservedsame vigorous epic rocking music that can make you kill more and more and more like the past (especially the later tracks, some of them are extremely nostalgic!)-Cons: (or compared with the classics)huge unique bosses are less than before, but understandablesome classic monsters don't show up, but ignorableKamikazes are far less than annoying due to mapping decisions, but bearablelacking of memorable encounters (I think)no dual revolvers (and swap trick)some finishing moves are not as good and should avoid to usesprinting mechanics could be done bettereven worse collision lets you jump around like a terrible painno stack/step jumping, no werebull riding, no rocket jumping(?)you can barely tell how far away from mobs by their sounds (or just my problem)so many casual fights in rather generic scenes across the campaign, could be too repetitive in coop mode (well for the series they all do)=Neutrals:faster keystroking combat but slower overall walkthrough (some may not favor the pace on first few levels, so as mini riddles and skippable cutscenes throughout the plot)crawling dungeons enhances immersion but somehow cripples fluency (all are short and could be tolerable)songs sometimes could go too serious but not 'serious'(Multiplayer and DLC untouched yet)

It can even run on a mobile processor so it should work well on a large variety of system specifications, however if you don't like the default you customise EVERY graphical setting and I mean everything, so there's a lot of mixing and matching settings which is brilliant. Keep in mind that if your looking for a typical COD clone then this game ins't for you.  It's combining new with old here.  Its more of an old school shooter.Killing enemies is also very satisfying, and you can even tear off heads, hearts and even eyes off enemies and throw them at other enemies. The game even has a seprate Moddable version that you get when buying the game, allowing you to use a whole wealth of workshop content to add new maps, enemies, game modes, weapons and more for free, but if you want to keep the game mod free you can also play the standard version which doesn't support mods.It also features full controller support right from the get go, which means this game works amazingly well with big picture mode or SteamOS.  And ..... it also has .... splitscreen .... seriously (no pun intended) which is rare for a PC game, which makes it even better that this game has controller support.I honestly cannot recommend this game enough, its well worth the price.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												Remember the good ol' days of fantastic first-person shooters? Remember shooters where you didn't have: turret sections, mud walking, quick-time events, extremely linear levels, pseudo-realistic themes, generic enemies, boring weapons and an all-MURICAN annoying storyline? Serious Sam 3: Before First Encounter remembers!The game is a prequel to Serious Sam: First Encounter of which the earth is suffering an apocalyptic alien invasion. You're Sam "Serious" Stone, official unbeaten badass, tasked with the rescue of an archaeologist, Professor Stein, to know the secrets of an ancient piece of alien technology located in the deserts of Egypt. Unfortunatley, the Professor is dead and it's up to Sam to solve all of the problems... and by "solve" I mean kill countless number of aliens! The story is simple and it's not the game's main purpose. You have very few characters and most of the ones you do meet end up dying shortly. The cutscenes are basic and their animations are average at least.  The voice acting is quite dodgy is some aspects, however, you'll have a good laugh with Sam's cheesy and funny one-liners. One thing that you'll see very different from other Serious Sam games is the theme. Instead of having a cartoony silly theme, like in previous Serious Sam games, Serious Sam 3 has a more realistic aesthetic to it. The guns look like generic variations from modern military shooters and part of the story is even similar to modern military shooters in terms of its scripting. However, I liked it since there wasn't too much of it to ruin the game and the enemies this time around look much cooler. Don't worry; Serious Sam 3 isn't serious at all! NETRISCA (Sam's database source embedded into his skull) makes its return along with Sam and they improved it's visual appearance along with the presentation of enemies and information. One problem that I have with it is the fact that it takes forever to see all of what the NETRISCA has to say, so everytime you wanna read the description of an enemy you're going have to wait for a couple of annoying seconds until you can read all you need to. But that's not a big issue. I wish NETRISCA could talk like JARVIS from Iron Man, which would be awesome!Let's start with the singleplayer campaign. So what is the formula of Serious Sam? The franchise has always concentrated in wave-based arena fighting of which you have to continuously move around the level to avoid damage and strike your enemies in the most efficient way. The slogan of the game, "All Man. No Cover!", is well implemented in the game, it's not just for marketing purposes. The point of Serious Sam is movement and avoiding projectiles as well as enemy melee attacks. It's quite fun doing so and simultaneously requires some skill. If you use cover and stick to one spot only, the game will punish since there is destructible terrain in the game and the enemies are will always close onto you fiercely.There is a big variation of enemies but some are missing from the original games of Serious Sam like the Beheaded Firecracker and the Reptolid (a very tricky one to put down). Fortunatley, you'll find some new enemies like Witch-Bride of Achriman, but I think enemy is badly used in most of the game. In some ways, she could be used as an enemy support-type. The worst enemy is the Technopolip, you can only bring this one down with explosives, I think it restricts the player's freedom of weapon choice and it's quite annoying to take care of. Also I think the Kleer Skeletons (undead horse-like mobile skeletons) are a little bit bullet-spongy than previous Serious Sam games, specially because when you encounter one, a million will follow behind him. I can safley say that the Kamikazes are back and they're still very satisfying to shoot at. I can state that the final boss fight is one the most epic, best and hardest ones I have ever played.Now the level design, a crucial portion of a Serious Sam game! There are some levels that are quite linear and are irritating to go through them since they keep chucking really bullet-spongy enemies at you and that breaks the pacing of the game. These levels go against the formula of Serious Sam but they're still fun. Serious Sam levels are vast of which gives you and the enemies space to maneuver. It may seem boring but you'll feel the pressure as enemies overwhelm you. The difficulty also changes the enemy placement and respawns and all of them are quite dynamic and different.Let's go to the weapons! The weapons have no recoil of any description but it's not a problem since this is an arcade-like game. Some are standard-type weapons (pistol, shotgun, assault-rifle) and the rest are seriously silly weapons (double-baralled shotgun, rocket launcher, automatic shotgun with high-explosive bullets and The CANNON!). In Serious Sam: First Encounter, the melee weapon was the horrible combat knife. The game threw a million enemies against you and the melee weapon was a knife that could only cut butter. Instead of that, Croteam introduced the Sledgehammer. I think it is a good addition to the series since it's responsive and causes a lot of bloody mess. There is no Grenade Launcher; this weapon was replaced with the Auto-Shotgun and that was a good replacement since the predecessor was very sluggish for a Serious Sam game. The Sirian Arm Tech is similar but more gorey, however, it's quite possibly one of the least enjoyable weapon because it takes too long to chop enemies into bits. Overall, these weapons of mass destruction are fun to use!Serious Sam 3: BFE brings back the massive 16-player Co-Op with a new mode: Co-Op Coin. This is a survival co-op hordemode of which you have to score as much as you can before the end of the match. In every so number of points, you get a license to kill and thus you can get to the top of the score board! If you don't like that mode then crank the difficulty up and shoot as many monsters and baddies as you can with your best friends with the standard Co-Op mode! Even though it is a Co-Op mode, you don’t have Co-Op specific functions, not even reviving; it’s only to play with friends. It’s still fun! There is also Competitive Mode but it's not as good as Serious Sam's fantastic Co-Op. In fact, it just makes the Co-Op look better since it’s unbalanced and there are only vanilla-type modes available.  The game has Steam Workshop which features new weapons, community-made campaign maps, graphical mods and code changing mods. So there is a lot to do after beating the original game.  The Serious Engine 3.5 makes a very good looking game and it’s very well optimized for PC! It features a ridiculous options menu, so ridiculous that you'll say to yourself: "YE GODS! LOOK AT ALL OF THOSE GRAPHICAL OPTIONS!". In fact, I consider this a new standard for graphical options for PC games. So if your machine runs on a potato, then fear not! But it is a little tricky to use and hard to understand. I had to research some of the options to know what they do. I think it would be best that the Serious Engine 3.5 had a more general options menu without leaving the more specific one out.Regarding the bonus pack, it will only add, in the game, a scope for the Auto-Shotgun, nothing special. The good part of it is the Making of Move and the awesome soundtrack! The music in Serious Sam 3 is much better considering the previous games of which mixes arabic-theme songs with rock music! Beautiful combination.Conclusion....buy the freaking game! It's worth every cent on the price tag and you will not regret for the love of JEBUS! Unless you're not man enough to take up some serious fights! I recommend it!

content:
Posted: August 22, 2013
												Serious Sam games have a special place in my collection. They made pure FPS carnage as fun as it gets. Many FPS games have great combat, but no other game delievered mass mayham as this series did. While the Second game (Serius sam 2 not the second encounter) was a bit questionable (though still good), this game far exceeded what I expected and become the best Serious Sam game to date (on my account anyway).First off a few changes and additions, for better or worse. Some weapons now have manual reloading and aiming down sight. For the most part this hardly has ANY impact on the gameplay. The formula is still the same as before. Go through levels slaughtering hundreds (and thousands) doing few simple puzzles, stomping few bosses etc. There are few distinct changes from the original games which may depend on your taste. The game is little bit less arcadey. It removed the powerups such as Serious Speed, Serious Damage, ammo packs etc. Now all pickups are individual. You can't pick up ammo in bulk anymore meaning you have to search more. Since ammo doesn't float in the air it is more hidden and requires more searching to survive. In my view this is a great thing. It puts stronger emphasis on secrets than ever before. Secrets now feel MUCH more relavent than before, and before they were rather important as well. The health and armor system are intact. Pickups for those just changed models but the function is identical to how it was. (you won't see regenerative health in this game, and shame on you if you even considered the thought).Next change is that you don't have double ammo capacity on Serious difficulty. This is offset by removing the insane claustrophobic encounters you had in first and second encounter. You won't get 30 kleers attacking you in a small enclosed room anymore. You won't have unfair enemy spawn around corner that you have to fully comit to memory or reload your game. There is a new melee finisher system. Most enemies you can outright kill via melee animation. This solves small encounters in enclosed space (from being a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥. but due to time it takes to perform one it isn't recommended for use in a larger fight so it balances it out nicely.The game focuses much  more so on open battles, but due to the improvement on the engine this is in a word glorious. Outside environemnts aren't just big yards anymore. There are buildings, walls, with half of them fully destructible. As rockets start to fly most of your cover will diminish forcing you to adapt, prioritize your targets and move quickly. I honestly didn't feel that the old formula would feel so fresh and fun again but hell it is and I can't stress enough how much fun it is. Your arsenal is nearly identical from the first two games but it did go through some refinement. Shotgun, Double Barreled Coach Gun, Minigun, Rocket Launcher, Sniper Rifle, Laser Gun, SBC Cannon. They are all present with few new additions to spice it up (devestator is tear jerking full of awesome). Models are new and updated as well as their sound. As for their balance and their purpose they are still as fans remember. You will kill a Kleer with a coach gun point blank. You can one shot a minor biomechanoid with a single rocket, etc. All the stuff you remember from first two games will carry over, you will know what gun to use on any old enemy without much thought. This is also the first SS game where two weapons are exclusive to secrets only. You won't find the lasergun and the sniper(and their ammunition) outside of secrets. *This changes in the DLC Jewl of the Nile*The game overall takes a contemporary shooter flavor if I would say. It shows us that you can create a modern shooter with old school mechanics and gameplay and create a quality product.Overall, for the fans of the series, this game might be conflicting for few changes, but safe to say most will embrace it an rejoice we have another Serious Sam game that is not just outstanding, but Seriously outstanding. For newcommers, you are in for a hell of a ride, get your guns at ready and Get Serious.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Serious Sam 3: BFE - The BFE stands for Before First Encounter, which makes this a prequel to the other Serious Sam games. The story is a simple but effective one - Aliens invade, lots of nasty critters, turn on and go to the time travel doodad and connect up to First Encounter to save earth. As a bonus, you get an auto-translator if you stare at text that shows you some more backstory and other bits of text.At first, it seems like Sam has been reduced to a generic military shooter. Instead of the bright and fast shooting from the Sam games before this one there are basic guns, a grey cityscape, and somewhat basic soldiers you need to shoot like just another chest high wall simulating shooter game. But as you progress you find more interesting things to fight, you get more options, you find the old enemies again, and the environment shifts from generic cityscape to more interesting environments. You get more weapons, and the generic soldier enemies are slowly phased out as you get further in. It once again makes shooting funWith large levels that have plenty of secrets hidden throughout them, exploring is rewarded. There seem to be a few new enemies but I do not think they all worked out that well. Of the ones I do not really like, one is mainly just annoying as it hides from you in what would otherwise be a fast paced game where you can go around avoiding everything through skill and proper manouvring, and the other uses magic to hold you in place in the air while shaking your aim. Luckily, these are not too common and the former can usually be ignored as you do not have to kill them to progress.As is expected of Sam, there is a good co-op mode that allows you to bring one or several friends with you, and the settings are as detailed as they always were to let you customise your experience. Difficulty is not a problem - Sometimes it may feel like you're up against nearly impossible odds, but with a little bit of skill and a little bit of luck you can get through it. While I would not say it is as good as First Encounter, it provides a very solid experience with plenty of amusing moments, Serious Sam 3: BFE will give anyone with an interest plenty of enjoyable hours of play - And then even more if they bring a friend

Posted: August 12, 2013
												Serious sam 3 is one of the few games where it wasn't as good as I remember it. At first I loved it like goty 2011 loved it. then I tried more classic fps ( rise of the triad,blood,shadow warrior,painkiller) and i can say that I feel like the game is average and that's gonna♥♥♥♥♥♥off people so just let me explain why. let's start off with the good it looks pretty,nice sound design, and the game is going back to what made the first encounter enjoyable. the music is a mix bag for me i don't know about you but I find the music to be dull mostly the music that fits with the enviornments personally i'd rather have music that gets you pumped for the action like say doom. the gameplay well they added some unecessary modern mechanics like the iron sights which are about as useful as driving with your head. one of my biggest issues is while it does go back to the old style of serious sam they could at least kept it fresh with say alternate ammo or firing modes and such. In terms of combat i think gamespot put it best "Action feels more like cleanup than combat" and that's what it felt like to me throuogh most of the game. the multiplayer is crap especially the deathmatch it's so unbalanced and the maps are poorly designed. The game has a rather inconsistant difficulty i'm not sure if it's fair or unfair i'm not sure cause the game didn't feel balanced to me. oh and also the game doesn't run well like framerate drops and starting it crashes it. so serious sam 3 is a mix bag for me it could have been better let's just say that i think there are better throw back fps like painkiller black or hard reset.  I'm thankfully not the only one who thought serious sam 3 was lackluster especially in comparison to the first game like this guy

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												This game is an absolute blast to play.  The game looks stunning even when using low settings.  The only bad point about the game is that the shotgun sounds way to weak. Get this game! Seriously ..... GET IT! It can even run on a mobile processor so it should work well on a large variety of system specifications, however if you don't like the default you customise EVERY graphical setting and I mean everything, so there's a lot of mixing and matching settings which is brilliant. Keep in mind that if your looking for a typical COD clone then this game ins't for you.  It's combining new with old here.  Its more of an old school shooter.Killing enemies is also very satisfying, and you can even tear off heads, hearts and even eyes off enemies and throw them at other enemies. The game even has a seprate Moddable version that you get when buying the game, allowing you to use a whole wealth of workshop content to add new maps, enemies, game modes, weapons and more for free, but if you want to keep the game mod free you can also play the standard version which doesn't support mods.It also features full controller support right from the get go, which means this game works amazingly well with big picture mode or SteamOS.  And ..... it also has .... splitscreen .... seriously (no pun intended) which is rare for a PC game, which makes it even better that this game has controller support.I honestly cannot recommend this game enough, its well worth the price.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Ok, so let's try to write a review without the word "Serious" in it. Ok, I just wrote serious -1- time, but it was to define goal. Ok, that's -2- now.So Serious Sam 3 (that's -3- but it shouldn't count coz it's the game name) is the best brutal & violent FPS I played in years. It's old-shool, like the FPS of the 90's where you actually needed skills, basic orientation capability (ie: you don't cry for mama coz you fear to get lost as soon as there's more than 1 possible path), and health management (no, hiding behind a wall won't give 100% of your health back in 2 seconds).So the game is tough, challenging, fun and well done visually (but not amongst the best) ; so if it's your kind of things, it's a no-brainer, get it already, seriously !( -4- ... Oh, jeez, who wrote this rule about no serious word anyway... -5- ... :-p )

												Great and fun sequel, but IMO the worst of the series. And what does that mean for the average player ? Nothing, because the older games in the series are so great I doubt it can get better than that. This one is just a bit less great. Most of the things I missed in this game were fixed in the Jewel Of The Nile maps.Positives:- great graphics- blood and gore- insanely huge maps- good soundtrack as always- multiple boss fightsNegatives:- can't compete with the greatness of The Second Encounter- modern Egypt doesn't look as great as ancient Egypt- they went too far with smoke, dust and debries- lack of use of harpies and sniper oriented battles (fixed in JOTN)So, basically the only negative thing about it is that older titles were too good :P

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Serious Sam 3: Brain ♥♥♥♥ed Eygptians is by far the most cleverly written political satire to ever grace the human race with it's iridescent presence. In the infinite wisdom from the omniscient immortals at Croteam, the vicious dictatorship of Hosni "Mental" Mubarak is expertly represented as a bunch of suicidal members of the Headless Horsemen's Al Qaeda Alien Death Sect, as the relentless try to halt the glorious charge of Arab Spring Sam.  Defining the phrase "crackling with sexual energy", Serious Sam 3: Big Fat Erections is the voice of a generation, it answers the call of gamers craving for something more daring, something more extreme, something to make them touch themselves more furiously and gasp gasmically at the mere though of a controller then any overpriced DLC pack ever could. It calls forth a tension that can only be unjustifyingly compared to being unwittingly caught with a stiffy at a pre-school and having to wade through a sea of reasonably horrified soccer moms and teen parents who shower you with fetuses from their unwanted pregnancies. Serious Sam 3: Boobs Feel Erotic was created with the worlds Macho-Powered Graphics engine which produces a plethora of visuals so real, that the animations are toned down by default to spare thy mind of trying to take in two identical realities at once, and any poor Icarus who dares try to fly higher and adjust the settings will be instantly rendered into a coma by the eye-meltingly good graphics that will literally cause them to drown in their own drool. All of this goodness is spliced in with some of the most dramatic character development ever fathomed by a college dropout from some♥♥♥♥♥♥hole in Europe, with Samuel being so overflowing with emotion, determination, wholesome relatability and butt jokes from 2006, that when the game ends their is a 78% chance the player will promptly suicide because they cannot fathom a world in which Cereal Sam is not by their side whilst gently caressing the back of their carpal tunnel riddled wrist.TL;DR It's dumb, cheap, rips off the plot from majora's mask almost as much as I rip off jokes from TBF, and it's got a helluva ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ripper for a final boss.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												This is what I like about first person shooters!Serious Sam 3: BFE is just pure monster blasting bliss. It's got a paper thin story peppered with sparse cut-scenes, some mild puzzle solving (find the key, blow up a wall here) and lots of great one-liners.No Hollywood actors trying to shoehorn in some absurd plot to immerse you in the realism of war, only a man, lots of guns and hordes of enemies to destroy with an arsenal that ranges from a sledge hamnmer, through your standard shotguns and assault rifles, to a massive cannon and semi automatic explosive shell launcher.The story takes you through the decimated streets of post alien invasion Cairo, under and through a museum, and then eventually deep into the desert and under the pyramids themselves. The developers do a pretty good job of getting a lot out of these big, fairly open levels, but there could have been a little more variety in later stages...your third set of Egyptian ruins starts to look a lot like your first pretty quickly. Where this game and other Sam games really shines, is the variety of enemies. Each with their own methods of attack that range from acid spitting bugs, to mindless shotgun wielding clone troopers, to charging alien bull-beasts, to leaping space monkeys, to mehanized reptialian dual rocket launching abominations...each one requiring a slightly different tactic in order to best destroy it. Serious Sam three won't just toss them at you here and there...it will send them at you in massive wave after wave, and it is so satisfying to take them down.So my overall thoughts: Serious Sam 3: BFE is a lot of fun. It's not deep, or cutting edge, but it's a great looking game that will throw a lot of action at you very quickly. It's kill or be killed, and I've really enjoyed the time I've spent playing.Pros: - Satisfying action- Big, challenging levelsCons:- Could use more level varietyFinal rating: ☺☺☺☺☺☺☺☺8/10 Happy ascii faces

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												Now that I've completed Serious Sam 1,2, and 3, I hope to release a YouTube video explaining how I feel about each game and how they hold up. But BFE alone? Honestly, the only real time I was frustrated with this game was when I made the leap from TOURIST mode to SERIOUS mode. Admitably, that was a dumb desicion. But why'd I do it? Because there are "achievements" rewarding you for completing the game on Serious difficulty. However, those 20-30 minutes of my little brother calling me out on me swearing under my breath taught me a valuable lesson. Life's not about how you get there, but what you DO to get there. If it's not worth it, then don't bother.Plus, it's super gorey. 9/10

content:
Posted: March 23, 2012
												The feel of the game is so similar  to the original, with all of the elements that you'd expect of  a Serious Sam game that I immediately felt at home; but with SS3  we get   even better looking, and in some cases,  scarier  looking monsters and  realistic looking weapons as well as fabulous  environments to run and gun around in.If you ever played the first two episodes when they were originally released   and  enjoyed the games because of the tongue in cheek violence, the various ways you could  change the look of the game to show gore,  hippie flower power or a child-like   expression of  blood as well as an over the top hero and waves of monsters, then you won't be  disappointed with  this new offering.  I've been waiting for SS3 to be released for years and am NOT disappointed with the result.  Croteam  have excelled.  There are so many great games being released at the moment, but for  pure unadulterated fun  this is one of the better releases over the last four or five months

Combat can be frustrating with odd hitboxes and the occasional clumsy pathfinding, and you're probably going to get sick of the Egyptian motif by the end of it, but this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is still going to be a blast from start to end. Don't feed the kleers.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Serious Sam 3: BFE is a old-school FPS game developed by Croteam and released in 2011. It is the latest game in the Serious Sam series and a prequel to Serious Sam: The First Encounter. The game's story takes place in the 22nd century, during Mental's invasion of Earth, as implied in The First Encounter. Like previous titles in the series, Serious Sam 3: BFE involves fighting against many hordes of enemies in wide-open environments. However Serious Sam 3 has more closed environments than its predecessors, particularly in the early levels. There are also a larger number of enemies that can attack the player from a distance.Now lets talk about the game shall we. While Serious Sam 3: BFG BFE is clearly a shooter that pays homage to the old-school PC shooters from the late 90's, all the way to 2004 (The end of the golden age of PC FPS games), it holds on to this vision of the past so hard, that it insisted to even bring back the old problems of the genre. While without a doubt this game has some really satisfying gunplay, interesting monster design, where it fall short is the level design, the voice acting, the soundtrack and the story. I know, it's a serious sam game, but they insisted on the story this time around (hence the cut-scenes and dialogue) but it's annoyingly bad. So, so bad. Sam's one-liners are even worse. An old, battered Sam feels like the return of Duke, in Duke Nukem Forever. The charm is just not there. Also, the game barely introduced anything new to the formula, it's just a HD remake of the same old formula, with the exception of a a handful enemy types. Talk about lazy designers. I guess Croteam don't want to traverse into unknown territory. As for the level design, the game starts out decent enough, the engine showcasing detailed buildings lying in ruins, once you get to the 2nd level, the game takes a massive turn to the worse. And there will be a theme repeating here. Once you get to the corridor shooting of Serious Sam 3, you can't turn back. The very thing they wanted to stand apart from, has crawled itself in here aswel. While not all the game is a "corridor theme", there are certain areas that will leave you extremely bored, or just unsatisfied. Piramids, ancient temples and such. And when finally you get to the arenas, you will find a tedious experience. Shooting wave after wave of enemies, collecting items and health packs, The fun of it all fades away pretty fast. Which brings me....FUN. Fun is the biggest issue with this game, you have none. This is more of a personal opinion, but honestly, blasting through all those hoards of never ending monters, just felt tedious, instead of fun. Especially in the later levels. It's just not there anymore, I didn't have much satisfaction dying instantly because the game throws dust in my face, and 100 hitscan enemies at once, while I get piled up by skeletons throwing chains at me. It's just infuriating at times, and while the game takes some patience, that patience is not rewarded enough. Secrets consist of small objects such as: mini health packs, armor shards and ammo. Not much if you ask me. The frustration builds up in the later levels when the game thorws enemies that jump all over the place, rockets that hit you with 70% accuracy and suicide bombers everywhere. It's not challenging if you just throw more enemies at once, at least build up a pattern. The last hour of the game will be a real letdown. Anyways, before I give the game a score, I'll just break it down into stuff I liked and disliked.The good:Old school run and gun mechanicsDetailed weapon models + really satisfying to use themDetailed enemy design (and interesting at times)No regenerating health / no cover system (this is a + for me)Fluid melee systemUnlimited sprintHundreds of enemies at once on the screen for you to shootOverall good intentions, but they fall flat because of some of the idiotic design choices.The badBoring level designSubpar voice acting and lame storyWeak supply placement on higher difficutlyOver powered hitscan enemiesShotgun penetration does not exist, as for the rocket launcher, the AOE is a joke.Unsatisfying arenasThe last two hours are utterly frustratingBad endingDead multiplayerIn the end of the day, if you find yourself with this game on a sale, I'd say you should think twice before purchasing this. It's not going to be the ride of your life, the older ones we're way better. Personal rating : 4/10

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												This game made me nauseous. Apparently it's a widespread problem and you will find a number of players requesting how to turn off camera bobbing. I can't remember, but I think it was setting "prj_bGameOptionViewBobbing=0" in the dev console (~ key).The first 2/3rds of the game is just painful to play though. They tried to add some kind of story and gentle intro into shooting cannonballs, and lasers, but they should have just skipped all that junk and got to the shooting cannonballs.The game itself has some pretty good moments near the very end of the campaign mode, but mostly this game just sucks. The problem is they got too serious about graphics and realism, which isn't what made the old Serious Sam games fun. It was just about running around and shooting lots of things really fast with ridiculous guns.There are a few good things to note, such as the destructable objects and envrionment, but mostly playing this was a waste of time for me.Serious Sam 3 BFE just doesn't have a lot going for it. I rate it in there with Duke Nukem, but at least it didn't take Croteam fifteen years to make.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												It feel like something is missing.  Compared to the previous installments.I remember moments from the other SS games.  The glee.  The bottomless clips without reloading.  The desire to put lots of bullets into anything anywhere.  Dodging incoming bullets.  Huge swarms,SS3 though?  I've spent a significant percentage of my time backpedaling.  And reloading.  And finding cover to not-die and reload.  And those stupid shotgun/rifle zombie have ACTUAL bullets instead of the proper magic missile things, which can't be dodged.  :(  There's swarms, and SOME guns are useful in the REAL fights, but overall, it's too much like the other shooters out there.For instance, the laser gun gets barely any play.  SS3 throws a lot of missile and C4 boxes around, but no infinite-ammo love for anything else.Multiplayer is vastly more sun than single again, though *incredibly* shorter given that all the time spent backpedaling and reloading is gone.I liked the level design of the previous ones, and wonder why a runner can end a map.  What was wrong with arena rooms gated by monster deaths, with a portal to let stragglers in?

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												This game made me nauseous. Apparently it's a widespread problem and you will find a number of players requesting how to turn off camera bobbing. I can't remember, but I think it was setting "prj_bGameOptionViewBobbing=0" in the dev console (~ key).The first 2/3rds of the game is just painful to play though. They tried to add some kind of story and gentle intro into shooting cannonballs, and lasers, but they should have just skipped all that junk and got to the shooting cannonballs.The game itself has some pretty good moments near the very end of the campaign mode, but mostly this game just sucks. The problem is they got too serious about graphics and realism, which isn't what made the old Serious Sam games fun. It was just about running around and shooting lots of things really fast with ridiculous guns.There are a few good things to note, such as the destructable objects and envrionment, but mostly playing this was a waste of time for me.Serious Sam 3 BFE just doesn't have a lot going for it. I rate it in there with Duke Nukem, but at least it didn't take Croteam fifteen years to make.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2012
												Pros:-Very pretty graphics (DX11 tessellation looks really cool)-Fast-paced, mindless kill-em-all gameplay-Decently long campaign-Awesome multiplayer-Some decently funny one-liners-Prolonged battles get the metal music goingCONS:-Hideously repetitive tedious chore of a last level-Enemy waves last a liiiiiittle too long (I found myself saying "Alright, ENOUGH!" more than a few times)-Stupid idiotic FPS cliches, like losing all your weapons mid-way through the game-Enemies spawn 1-2 at a time, which provides zero challenge, and is nothing more than an exercise in patience. The music switches from calm to energetic about 30 times while this happens, as well-Sound design is HORRIBLE. Enemies that are literally 200 feet away sound like they're right behind you-Enemies can shoot you from the other side of the map with a shotgun-Some extremely annoying enemiesOverall this is an enjoyable game that gets rather annoying in long play sessions. Don't spend more than $10 on it.

												The game has some flaws, like some enemies being annoying because you can't dodge their bullets, and some weapons needed to reload. These flaws mostly show during the first couple of stages. I also really hated the dark stages. The game gets much better later however and becomes a classic. You start getting weapons that don't need to reload, the enemies become dodgeable, and the game just becomes much more fun. The final stage is awesome too. The graphics are also awesome, though I feel there's a CPU bottleneck. I recommend this. Advice: disable gaussian blur in the graphics options when you play.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Large Open Area NPC Spam 3: BFE:You best enjoy running backwards and shooting while being bum-rushed by a horde of obnoxious monsters, because that's what you'll be doing for about 80% of this game. Hardly any thought seems to have been put into the gameplay.I appreciate the effort to keep alive the traditional FPS style, but this fails to bring much beyond the excessive shooting of repeated enemies. There's some novelty: using a new weapon in the arsenel, encountering a new enemy, fighting a massive boss. The novelty quickly fades. The game is a tedious chore after everything's been thrown at you for the hundredth or even thousandth time. It doesn't matter how destructive the weapons are, or how bizarre the enemies are, when there's little deviation to the scenery, level design and pacing.I'll commend the tech beneath the game, on the other hand. Everything has a good amount of detail visually, and the engine functionally handles a ton of different effects (many of which can be tweaked in the options for optimization). If only more of that effort were put into the actual game...
